My friends and I came last weekend to see the Disney After Dark burlesque show, and all of us loved it. We laughed our asses off. Don't get me wrong, there were sexy moments too. And live singing, which I definitely wasn't expecting! The show featured characters like Beast, Ursula, and Maleficent. Maleficent and Ursula, both drag performers, were absolutely fantastic. I really liked the balance of men, women, and drag that were all here. Way to be inclusive, 708!

We also had drinks. Two (of the four) of us were a little bummed because we wanted to try a cocktail called the Cruella de Ville, but they were out of one of the ingredients. It was a definite bummer but, stuff happens. Our "cocktail kitten" (I believe her name was Serenity?) was super sweet and apologetic about it. Instead I had a Lost Boy and a Tarzan, both were well poured and good, though I preferred the Lost Boy. I loved that the servers were dressed in burlesque style outfits as well- the one dressed like Alice is stunning. Our server was super cool about taking the Yelp discount, and was just overall really attentive and nice. 

After the show, we grabbed a few drinks at the bar. The bartender was super nice and attentive. The cocktail kittens were friendly and energetic and danced and talked with us, which I appreciated because all four of us were women. I was happy to see that they weren't just focusing on the men (which I've seen at other bars). I took a selfie with one of them, and she let us know if we checked in on Facebook we'd get a free shot. Which, who says no to a free shot?

We wandered outside to drink, and it was just a really great night. I'm not from the area, and have never been on that block in STL before. Everyone was really friendly and chill, the weather was warm. There was just a nice (and safe) vibe all around. 

I will definitely be back. Hopefully, to try the food next time as well. Thanks for a great night, Seven Zero Eight!

Liked the vibe and decor of this place. Friendly bartenders, amazing beer & wine selection and a wide variety of new american tapas..if I lived here, I would go to Tria at least once a week.  Loved that it was right across the street from my hotel- made it so easy to go and grab a glass of wine and a small plate while waiting for my friends to get ready back at the hotel.  Reminds me of a couple great wine bars in San Francisco that I love.

Being a fan of the Taproom, I immediately fell in love with Bottleworks and all Schlafly products. The bartenders at this particular location are extremely friendly, and I even scored a free beer on my last visit. 

The outdoor patio is awesome on warm days. Although only a small part of it is reserved for those not ordering food. The covered patio is for patrons who are eating. Something to keep in mind if you are with a larger group. 

On my brother's last day visiting me in St. Louis, he insisted I drive him here to pick up some shirts for his friends back home in SF. He ended up walking out of there with over a $100 worth of loot. I am going to go ahead and say Schlafly left a good impression on that dude!

Great spot to enjoy the morning sun and your coffee. Order and pay on the counter then pick an emoji for them to bring your order later. Outdoor seating available. Great ambiance.
Fresh ingredients,great portions!
Love the hash!

this place used to just be called Lamberti's. no idea why they changed the name at some point - everything is just as good as it has always been, if not better!
this place is a standby favorite for my family. it is ALWAYS good. you can count on consistency, quality, and service. we made it our go-to spot when we moved to cherry hill in 1992, and we'll keep on going there.
you can usually get a reservation, even for a big group. they will never turn you away or make you wait too long - it's a family spot and all group sizes are embraced.
try their marsala, aribiata, and puntanasca. their tomato bread is OUTSTANDING. they do seafood extremely well. their specials are outstanding.
bring gum or mints... you will consume about 5 cloves of garlic with any dinner. but i wouldn't have it any other way.

We enjoyed a fantastic Valentine's Day dinner at Americano and my mouth is watering in anticipation of our next visit.  We ordered exclusively off the tapas menu and tried most of the offerings.  We especially enjoyed the blood sausage, patatas bravas, and the friend manchego.  The sangria was excellent as well.  I'd love to see them offer gambas a la gabardina but the gambas ajillo were certainly a delicious (and healthier!) option.  Service was excellent and our food came out almost instantly.  The ambiance is pleasant and the prices are extremely reasonable.  Americano is an all-around win.

Mr. B's Bistro's greatest challenge is its name. Something about the name really doesn't seem nearly as classy or sophisticated as other great restaurants in the city, so much so that I almost passed on this one. Very glad I didn't.

Mr. B's has classic straightforward Louisiana and American food. The restaurant is elegant, yet accessible to everyone looking for a fine dining experience. (You could dress up or simply dress well and be at home here.)

I was delighted by this place in three ways:

1. Impeccable service. There was never a nearly empty glass of tea, and the server was simply among the best in her profession. The wine pairings she chose were also spot on.
2. Everyone at my table loved their meal. My steak was perfectly cooked and seasoned. The pear salad was delicious, having the right balance of cheese, dressing and pear. The seafood gumbo and redfish garnered rave reviews from others in my party.
3. The setting of the restaurant is also very relaxed. There were a few families with children here as well as all-adult tables and everything seemed as calm as it could be. You are steps from all the action of the French Quarter, but feel worlds away in here.

If you want to have a delicious meal, this is it. I especially recommend Mr.B's if you have a party with diverse palates. You can have spicy or simple here. Cajun or Southern.

Extremely friendly staff.  Loved the vibe inside, but it can get very packed so it may not be the best place to study or if you needed quiet time.

Cappuccino was very good and the chocolate chip cookie was delicious!  Love that they have complimentary sparkling water on tap too.

I love this place! I have been coming here for coffee, breakfast, lunch and to study since I was in high school. For the most part, the people are very friendly. The food is good- I especially like the breakfast sandwiches, the soups, the burger, the chicken sandwich, the club and the chicken tenders. Their burger specials are often really great and creative. The iced tea and frozen coffee are delicious! It's a cute atmosphere with a few quieter tables upstairs and a few outside as well. A great place to grab a bite or a coffee!

The pharmacy here is incompetent. I don't throw this word around lightly, but we are talking truly should be shut down. They have given me the wrong medication, and would have given me the wrong medication several times after that if I was not on top of my own medical care. If anyone receives multiple medications or the lesser love you miss you want you who may be easily confused, this is a place to stay away from.

The grits are thick, coarse, and super creamy.  A bit too thick for my liking but still tasty. The breakfast burrito was just as delicious as the BEST sandwich but $30 for 2 (small) burritos with grits and 2 coffees, is bit outrageous.  

I'm in love with refuel and my wallet hates me.

I really dig this place.

I dig the local vibes.  I dig friendly, laid back staff.  I dig baristas that actually know how to steam milk and achieve true microfoam.  I dig espresso that isn't bitter or acidic.
I dig a coffeeshop that likes to showcase local talent (music, poetry, and art).
I dig the plentiful, varied seating. I dig homemade pastries.  [I dig that the pastry flavors change daily which actually tells me they're homemade and turning over.] I dig homemade mocha syrup.

Yeah, ok, some pastries don't blow my mind as people have already said, but they do admittedly taste homemade in lovely imperfection.  And that quiche looks so tempting.

Seriously though, I think this is my favorite spot in Haddonfield.

About a year and a half ago, my then-boyfriend and I were in New Orleans and took the Strange True tour with Jeffrey. It was a small group (5 people), and we loved it. I had been to New Orleans several times and taken a few of those big-name tours, so I thought I was going to get a lot of redundant information, but we didn't. Not only was the content great, but Jeffrey was a great storyteller and if you had any questions, he had answers. I could tell immediately that he enjoyed his job and actually cared about being a good storyteller, unlinke some other tour guides that I've had who were just going through the motions.

Fast forward a year and a half, and then-boyfriend is now my husband, and we were back in New Orleans for our honeymoon! I decided to book us on their bike tour, the cemetary tour, and the ghost tour. All of them were fantastic. And this time, we met Jeffrey's wife, and she gave us the cemetary tour. She's just as good of a storyteller as Jeffrey, and we got to watch her yell at someone who was writing "XXX" on Marie Leavau's tomb. (You shouldn't do it, it's disrespectful. And a felony.)

The bike tour was lots of fun, and we got to see areas of the city close to the French Quarter but a bit beyond walking distance. The ghost tour was interesting, and the only tour of the three this time that had other people on it. Being the night before Halloween, there were more people on the tour than normal - but it was still only a group of 10 people! We were walking by groups of 30ish people, and I can't imagine trying to deal with that many people while trying to jockey for good position to hear the story. Blah! I have no idea how Jeffrey can afford to keep his groups so small, but I'm glad he makes it a priority - it really adds to the enjoyment of the couple hours you'll be spending with him.

If you're still on the fence....just take one of his damn tours already. You won't regret it.

Whole Paycheck, yes, it is.  I stopped in quickly and just picked up a few items plus 2 pizza slices, and I spent nearly $50. Gulp. Their bottled tangerine Italian sodas are totally addicting, so I treat myself to them if I come here.  And I must say, I still really love their pizza. Their special was 2 slices for $7.

Free good wifi and yes, they make it really easy to stop after shopping to enjoy eating and relaxing here.

Had a lot of fun here last night.  This place is pretty nice for the most part.  They need more tables in the back area for people who do not want to stand close to the stage.  The drinks were kid of pricey but that is expected at a concert venue.  The bathrooms were pretty clean for the most part.  The sound was pretty good too.  I have been here twice and both times the upstairs was closed.  Bummer.  I would love to check it out.  There was a lot of little kids running around having fun which was pretty cool.  Made the place seem happier.  I will definitely be back.

After finishing my meal at Abyssinia, I sit here thinking to myself and wondering why I have never tried Ethiopian food before. I must say it was quite the experience. I live up on the North Side around 116th & Ditch road and it's a bit of a hike to get down there, but today I said what the heck and headed down to the little strip mall that houses Abyssinia and several other worth while "joints" as well! Having never done this I wanted to read up on it a little which actually helped me and I knew what to expect at least as far as tradition went. I chose the spicy lentil pouch to begin. Similar to a beef patty but triangular and stuffed with spicy lentils. This was awesome and piping hot! Then I got a recommendation from the server and ordered the sampler platter. This says, on the menu, that it comes with beef chicken and spinach in various ways of preparation. It sounded very good. Because I've never eaten goat and was a little apprehensive I wanted to stay away from it my first time out. When my order came out it had.... Well..... I really had no idea what it had!!! The dish came served on injera with rolls of Injera on the side. Injera is a very spongy almost rubbery flat bead that has little holes in it like an English Crumpet. The trick is to rip off a piece and scoop up whatever it is you've been eyeing on the dish! This was fun for me because I started to have wondrous flashbacks of all the times my mother would yell at me to get my hands out of the food and here I was digging, scooping and squeezing my way through an absolute heavenly plethora of spices, flavors and self made concoctions from my plate. I was a little afraid to ask what I was eating because it was so good I didn't want to know, YET! Of course I waited till the last piece of injera was gone and tried to eat the flattened out piece on my dish that had been there to form the wonderful spongy cradle soaking up all the flavors. The problem was I was stuffed and couldn't enjoy this last little tidbit. Just for the record, on my plate was some type of curried lamb. I love lamb but this was a little tough ( hence the 4 stars). I feel it could have been cooked to tenderize a little better. Chicken in a dark BBQ looking curry and cumin flavored sauce which was excellent. A sort of creamed but not creamed spinach, if that even makes any sense, at least that's how it tasted. Some curried potatos in the center of the dish several hot spices that I was warned by the server to go easy on (Really not that spicy ) But the best, to my surprise, was the Goat!!! It was extraordinary. So much that I could probably bathe in it. I'm mentally bathing in it right now while  I recount the tender, full of flavor spiced Goat.  Why have I not ever eaten this before. The server was extremely pleasant and attentive and the chef actually came out to my table and asked how I liked everything. I couldn't have like it any more. I will say this, I will come back. I can see me regularly ordering the spiced Goat and indulging with fingers grasping the injera to cradle the love on that plate.

The decor and atmosphere of the restaurant was really cute and country like. I love the wooden furniture and all. Our waitress was super sweet and checked on us regularly. I ordered the hot chicken sandwich with truffle fries. The sandwich wasn't as hot as I'd hoped, but I also have a pretty high heat tolerance so most food isn't. The sandwich was juicy and flavorful, though, so I'd definitely order it again. I've found a new love for truffle fries recently so I approve of the ones here. A girl friend that I was with never had them before so when she tried it for the first time, she instantly became addicted. I look forward to trying more of their menu.

Quick service, friendly staff, and MAN-O-MAN do I LOVE the Chick-fil-a sauce. Chick-fil-a used to be my favorite fast food chicken sandwich, that was until I found PDQ! I still think Chick-fil-a is a good sandwich, don't get me wrong, but PDQ is probably twice as good, and it is definitely not twice the price.

I still love the waffle fries and PDQ does not have Chick-fil-a sauce, but I am sure that I will be making less stops at Chick-fil-a now that I found PDQ.

Growing up in Michigan, we did not have Chick-fil-a. That being the case, I immediately became a fan upon moving to Florida. I have even gone so far as drawing cow spots on blank paper and taping them to by business suit to get my free chicken sandwich.

I always go with the #1 and cover that baby in the Chick-fil-a sauce. I also give my fries a hefty dose of salt and pepper and then proceed to dip them in the Chick-fil-a sauce. I have it down to a science. I even started making my own fried chicken sandwiches at home and took steps to make them more Chick-fil-a-ish.

Now that I found PDQ I have a huge internal conflict. I sure hope Chick-fil-a can drop the price of their #1 by a little bit, and then they may win my heart back, even though PDQ has a leg up on quality.

We stopped by Tria for after-dinner drinks following after a particularly filling dinner at Morimoto. I ordered a Greek red (Xinomavro) and it was excellent. The service was lax, but attentive at the same time. I particularly enjoyed the vibe of this place; it's where I would love to have a first date. It's comfortable, intimate, and has a great selection of nibblers, wine, and beer.

Take your girl (or guy) out here for a Friday night glass (or five!) of wine and see where the night takes you.

A regular stop on our errand circuit and a godsend during the winter months.   The positives are the generally good prices, the regular appearance of high end items (such as black garlic, purple asparagus, figs and heirloom tomatoes),  the sizable  array of chilis and peppers and the lovely, fresh flowers.   A concrete example of PJ's great pricing:  Three bunches of cilantro for $2 versus one bunch for $1.99 at Tanner's.   

The downsides are the divided fruit and vegetable counters forcing a shopper to stand in multiple lines, the uneven produce quality (some items appear to be seconds) and unreliable inventory (can't rely on any particular item being in stock) and the cash-only sale terms.  I also don't love the fact that you can't select your own fruit and veggies (pre-bagged) and the absence of scales so you can check the weight of items.

Two years later and Al & Co at Falconworks continue to impress and completely spoil us for any other mechanic.  We now take all our cars here to do any sort of work needed. The staff has been nothing but upfront, helpful and understanding, and we have zero complaints. 

As for the reason behind the update, my boyfriend loves unique cars and has a hard time finding a good mechanic to deal with them.  We started bringing all of them to Al and he not only gives us great work, but seems to love doing it too.  We recently picked up a new 'project' in the form of an old FJ55.  From top to bottom Al has had great recommendations for the future of the car and has bent over backwards to help us manage the restoration.   He loves servicing old and/or unique automobiles and is great about doing research and contacting vendors that may have that hard-to-find part or advice you need.  His shop has even fabricated some of the parts we couldn't find.  Throughout this process we had times where we were the typical 'difficult customers', changing our minds about what we wanted done, not returning calls, having issues getting our paperwork in order, calling just to ask for advice, and not only has the staff here taken it in stride, but have been positive and patient with everything.

Al truly loves his craft and is dedicated to making sure you not only get quality mechanic work, but takes time to explain (in person) what he is doing and why.  They also hate to take shortcuts and would rather do the best work possible once instead of fixing a symptom, but not the issue. I think out of everything, this is what I appreciate most about their service.

Ah Peppermill, home for the weekend. I enjoyed my stay at this hotel, I tend not to when there's a casino involved but I've learned to let my bf enjoy gambling while I enjoy sleep. One of the things I really liked was the landscape video slideshow, lots of Costa Rica footage which coincidentally is where my girl friends and I will be vacationing soon! Not to mention slides of Seattle which is where I'm pining to live. The large tvs are everywhere in the hotel/casino, it gives you something to look at while in line for the buffet, waiting for someone or when people watching isn't enough. We skiied for 2 days out of our 4 day trip and the Mt Rose shuttle picked us up directly in front of the hotel (in an airport shuttle, FYI: the REAL airport shuttle says Peppermill on it!) One of the first nights, we wandered around and found the bar across Biscotti's with music and singers, those singers can sing! I loved the rendition of Tainted Love. The trumpet player could use a little practice though, his playing was over powering and choppy when I think he meant to compliment the song with accents. The bar stocked Yamazaki whiskey which has been a fun find for my bf. The Island Buffet was ok, I wouldn't stand in line for it again, although there were a ton of various crab dishes and crab legs available. The spa was AMAZING. The smoke level at this casino seemed more tolerable than other casinos, Atlantis was gross in comparison. I hear they utilize air filters separately from built in systems to deal with the smoke. My favorite part of the trip was that we didn't have to rent a car, very rare for our travels.

So glad Mimi's is finally opened! It provides a great option for pizza, cheesesteaks and salads in Cherry Hill. The prices are very reasonable and they have a wide variety on the menu! 

We called for pick-up and got a bunch of different things so we could try a little of everything and share in a big group. We did a cheesesteak, pizza steak, buffalo chicken cheesesteak, fries, and mozzarella sticks. The owner was so nice and since they were closing he gave us 6 slices of pizza free!! 

The cheesesteak was great. Much better than a lot of other places in the area. You get a big hoagie stuffed with meat and cheese. The pizza steak was also delicious with a nice tomato sauce. 

The buffalo chicken cheesesteak was really good! It is spicy and definitely has a nice amount of sauce on it. There were big hunks of bleu cheese which I'm not a huge fan of but I know some people like! 

The mozzarella sticks come with like 8 to an order and were good. They tasted almost homemade! And we got a nice big order of fries for the side. 

The pizza slices were gigantic. The crust is the perfect amount of crispness and we really liked the flavor. My sister loved he tomato pie while I preferred the white pizza with broccoli and tomatoes. 

We will definitely order from Mimi's again and are happy to have them in the neighborhood! The owner is super friendly and we can't wait to try more. I believe they will have delivery or do already as well!

I must say by recent visit to Duckweed Urban Market was quite a shock and a surprise. I'm a Native and never imagined that a hip, trendy independent store would be lurking in downtown Tampa. I can imagine it in Seminole Heights,  but it blows my mind that it is in the downtown district.
This hidden gem offers such as assortment and variety of products for a small store. They had a few items I had been on the lookout for, but had been unable to find. PB2 is a ground powder of peanuts that you reconstitute with water and have a much more fat free peanut butter, they had 2 or 3 varieties. 
Artic Zero, a wholesome ice cream substitute is 150 calories per pint! Yes, you read that right & and as an ice cream lover, I have really been wanting to try this product.
This small grocery store carries a diverse selection of various wines and beers. Many products are locally grown, made, packaged...all Tampa area. They have a fresh produce area, homemade butter, homemade all kinds of products,  it was incredible. For a small store I spent over an hour perusing their offerings.
They have a deli full of many Boar's Head products, other tempting and tantalizing products & they also sell various fish & seafood & specialty delights. There is a juice bar & a bakery & a coffee bar, everything looks so tempting! There are pre made sandwiches,  wraps and specialty items as well as their regular menu & specials. I took home some mayo free homade tuna, it was absolutely delicious,  so light and flavorfull. Duckweed also has various frozen foods answer a wide assortment of juices. To meet all needs they also have staples like cereal, oatmeal, flour, toothpste... something for everyone.
Yes, this was quite a pleasant surprise and exciting for me as well as Tampa. Service was very pleasant and helpful. If I want to be picky, I would like to see some fresh pasta, more appetizer types of meat and lower prices. I understand it is a mecca of unique products, but I think some of the prices could be adjusted.
It is not real easy to access, but definitely worth the effort. I will definitely be a repeat customer. That tuna will always have a special place in my tum!
What's a girl to do?  Always keep her eyes open to new ventures and food opportunities.

This Wawa is allegedly the highest grossing Wawa in the country. The reason for this is because it's right next to Penn's biggest freshman dorm, and it's open 24 hours. If you come here on a weekend night, there will be an abundance of drunk college kids, and you will have to wait a very long time to get any food. They usually don't have enough staff to keep up with the higher demand either.

But apart from that, Wawa is an amazing convenience store. They have a great selection of custom made food ranging from hoagies & sandwiches to frozen beverages to mac & cheese to quesadillas. Most of it isn't amazing, but it's really good when you're starving and need something cheap and filling. I also love Wawa's self service milkshakes. They of course also have the usual snacks and beverages of a regular convenience store.

We were staying at the hotel across the street and this was a convenient place and we had observed people sitting outside and having a good time the night before.  We went for an early-ish dinner and sat at the bar.

While it is on the tail end of the crawfish season, they had them and it was something I had been wanting to try.  My wife ordered Pao Shrimp tacos.  I got a pound of crawfish and when they were served, the server/bartender demonstrated how to rip off their heads and get the meat out.  And, NO, I did not suck the heads.  They were great and so were the potatoes and sausage that came also.

My wife loved her tacos and compared them favorably to some we get back home called Bang Bang Shrimp at a place called BoneFish.

The conversation with the server was great and people started coming in in groups.  Seems like a very popular place.

The deduction of a star is the beer selection.  Only one local and that was Abita Amber and the rest was so-so kinds of options.

Nice atmosphere, nice conversation, good service and good food.

I just love coming here. 

The shoes are great, local beers on tap, they have wine, food, air-conditioning - why did we leave again?

I made a lane reservation by email on a Saturday for that evening  - no big deal... they responded quickly, although they do recommend emailing for reservations the day beforehand.  If you want a guaranteed reservation - go a little early, like before 8. It got pretty busy, but they did the best they could getting everyone set up to play with all the calls and walk-ins - those gals on the desk were mavens of organization.

Really, the tunes are pumping (and quality), the scoring is automatic, (which is great - I suck at it), and the feel of the place... really sends you back in time. The crash of the balls, the pins, the happy folks - whether or not they are 300 bowlers (heck, I'm happy to break 100!), we always have a great time.

For 2 people 2 frames, shoes and a beer (I was too full from supper), was... $43 We had a ball.  

I know they have live music from time to time, and hey - FRED PENNER was there last Friday.  I couldn't leave the house because of the air quality, but they have all the feels!

The only negative - and they can't help it, is the stairs.  Bowling alleys in basements were the norm when this one was built, so stairs.  There are larger stalls in the washrooms though.  Give them a call, before you go if you have mobility needs, and maybe there is an elevator somewhere that isn't up front.

This gem is our favourite in town... it's close, but if you plan to go in July - call first as it's their low season and they might be on vacation or undergoing needed maintenance!

CASH ONLY VENUE PEOPLE!
(And BYOB)

Cute little nook of a place nestled right on the corner.

The menu boasts eclectic style brunch foods and I found myself struggling on what to choose!

I ordered:
-- Toad in a hole: Hollandaise soaked challah, poached egg, jack cheese, truffle oil 
This was delicious and if you like poached eggs and are looking for a change to the normal eggs benedict (which is a fav of mine) this is a great option!  It is loaded with cheese!
--and Strawberry banana French toast for the table which was a weekly special
Honest;y, I really wanted to like this French toast but it lacked luster if you will...It sounded much better than it tasted.  It was a bit bland and not very sweet.

It is also a lil pricey so come prepared

I love brunch venues and may opt to re-visit this location

It's so pretty!!! Is the staff nice? Nope! But, it's pretty :) Also, it's very easy travel. 

I appreciate the drive thru drop off zone but do with it was longer or wider, it's a bit tough during peak holiday travel with people driving thru like maniacs. (confession, I am most likely categorized as one of those maniacs) 

The only time I use this station is to hop on up to NYC and it's a super easy ride. It's 1 1/2 hours and you have time to sit back and relax while charging your phone in the outlet next to your seat, score! The seats are huge so you have tons of personal space. 

They still have an old school board to show departure times and stairways. Love the sound it makes. I could stare at the ceiling for hours too. The architecture is stunning. It's very open and not stuffy and they keep it very clean. 

I appreciate the shopping they have in here too, great spot to grab a book and a snack while you are waiting. 

A lovely experience. I truly can't imagine driving to NYC again.

Came here because a dear friend gave me a gift card.

I'm sorry to say that Allegro il Gelato has completely spoiled my tastebuds. Completely. Obviously Frost has struck a chord here in Tucson, with all of its fans giving high reviews here and its many franchised stores. Me thinks that many, if most, have not tried Allegro's.

OK, I start sampling flavors. I think I'm going to try as many in-common flavors as Allegro's for a fun comparison. Start with one of my perennial favorites--salted caramel. Yuck. Tastes artificial. OK, cinnamon next. Nope. The same. This is not good. Two of what should be home run flavors foul out. Maybe a fruit flavor will be better. Strawberry. Ugh. Tastes like grocery strawberries. (Coming from CA, that's NOT a compliment. How *does* Ivan at Allegro Gelato get his to taste so much like fresh CA freshberries?!!!) Only three flavors and already my mouth is "frosted."

My wife tried Peanut Butter Crunch, Pumpkin, and Cinnamon. She said they all kind of tasted the same. She loves anything peanut butter. She passes.

She ends up with Cookies and Cream. It's OK. In desperation, I try chocolate. Acceptable.

After experiencing Allegro Gelato, it was disconcerting to watch them just slap the gelato in the cup. Almost unappetizing. I'm thinking, "You're not slinging mortar to lay bricks! Isn't your product better than that?"

I liked the flakes of chocolate in my flavor. It gave it a little nice texture to it. But let's compare other qualities. The texture of Frost in this chocolate was not bad. The texture in the other flavors were more "airy" than at Allegro. One thing that struck me was that with Allegro's gelato, there is a wonderful after taste that lingers on the taste buds like a romantic memory on my palate. 'Twas not so with Frost. The flavor was only present when it was in my mouth.

Like Allegro, Frost has a round cookie (see photos) they put in the cup of gelato. It is a cheaper cookie than the hazelnut cream filled pirouettes you get at Allegro. I mean it's a good cookie, but I'm comparing here, and it is not of the quality at Allegro.

The spoons. Ah, here is where they outshine Allegro. They are multi-colored mini spade-like paddle things. And bigger than what Allegro uses. They are kind of cool.

Prices are comparable with Allegro. Service is really good. My server always called me "sir." Many employees on a Friday night made for fast service.

So bottom line is Frost is OK. At least the chocolate. The rest tastes like medicine to me. Will you Frost fans, who obviously have fallen in love with gelato, go give Ivan's gelato a try? He's not only Italian (like the owners of Frost, I understand) but he got his degree in Italy at the gelato university in Bologna.

Two or three stars?....Oh...I don't know...."Meh, I've experienced better"...Yeah, I guess so.

Being in a low carb diet sucks when you LOVE and BREATH for pasta and bread. However, I just had the most amazing Zoodles delivered to our office meeting! They were marinated perfectly, the chicken was tasty, the sauce so good that my only complain was that they didn't put enough of it on my dish, and most importantly, it satisfied my craving for pasta while not compromising my dietary restrictions. This will definitely become a go to for healthy meals!

I've always wanted to ride on a cruiser along the beach. If that's what you're looking for - come here and rent from Wheel Fun Rentals!

Pros:
Plenty of bikes (cruisers have 3 speeds, mtn/terrain bikes - whatever you prefer)
Bikes for families (seats 2-4 adults and 2 small children or a puppy in the front)
Location is prime
2nd hr free coupon on a near by downtown info table (i love finding coupons)
Baskets & Helmet options (no extra charge)

Cons:
Service is slow 
Returning our bikes too around 10-15 min

My 1+ and I went on our Santa Barbara coast biking journey - leaving it open ended as to how long we'd keep the bikes.  After 2 hours - I was done haha.  So the coupon for the 2nd hour free worked without any problems. 

If I came back, I'd definitely rent from them again!

It's the biggest and the best for a reason!

My parents brought us here on spring break when we were kids (Disney was out of our price range), and I brought my 4 1/2 year old cousin here over the weekend, along with my cousin (her mom), and my own mom. It was so much fun! I loved the costumes display...as most adults will. I was especially excited about the Star Wars items and the Ghostbusters costume. My mom got a kick out of the Whoopi Goldberg from Ghost and Laverne outfits. The 4 year old liked dressing up in the various play costumes in front of the mirror. 

She liked climbing all over the stuff in the Dora exhibit and all 3 generations enjoyed the Barbie exhibit. The little one tried on lots of costumes and walked the runway, and we all drew outfit designs from various fabrics and magazine photos. New word for her: inspiration. Lots of boys were really enjoying the Barbie exhibit too.

She planted some seeds in the Biotechnology Learning Lab, rode the carousel, used several computer learning stations, helped sift sand to find fossils, and climbed around in the play areas. 

Our lunch was good too. There were fun kids meals like mac & cheese and potato smiles available, but we ended up going with pizza, breadsticks, a cheeseburger & fries, and a turkey sandwich. There is a nice selection of "adult" food like potato salad and multigrain sandwiches with gourmet aiolis alongside the hot dogs and finger foods. Milk, soymilk, juice, water, and dinosaur-shaped sugary drinks are available.

At the end of the day she told me she was going to come visit me "all the time" so that we could have "lots of fun at the Museum".

I had the best breakfast experience at Refuel Cafe recently. 

Awesome people - The girl at the counter that took our order was cheerful, friendly and patient...everything you could want from someone taking down your breakfast order. She spoke with excitement about the food and was right on point with her recommendations. 

I ordered the veggie breakfast burrito which was pressed to make the wrap nice and toasty. The ranchero sauce is delicious and and feel free to be liberal with those dunks because its made from greek yogurt so its totally healthy. Win! 

Please allow me to write a separate paragraph about the grits. As I wipe away a tear from my eye just thinking about the creamy consistency that one only gets from a grit after whisking for an hour an a half. The owner explained it's a true, "labor of love" and you can tell he loves his customers because he only serves food that is delicious and fresh. 

I can see myself becoming a regular at Refuel for the fun and friendly people, the bright interior with natural sunlight pouring in from every direction, the oversize mug with fresh brewed coffee, and lets not forget the food, ehem, grits.

I love my morning coffee.  Someone must have told all of the servers at Honey's Sit-N-Eat, because three different servers asked us four separate times if we wanted a refill.  The space is small and drafty, but cute.  It reminds me of the Pacific Northwest, and I get all misty-eyed.  I digress... back to the food.  I got eggs with nova lox mixed in, with grits and sausage.  Bonus for the sausage having a sweet flavor to it.  I prefer nova to stand alone, and not be mixed in with the eggs, oh well.  The only thing "southern" about this place is the grits, and not really.  Honey's grits are thick, whereas I've always eaten smooth and creamy 'southern' grits.
Great quaint place. Service was good food was really good, sat outside, brought my dog, they were even attentive to her.  I would love to go back and try more items on the menu.

Excellent cappuccino, one of the best I've had in Indy (4.5 stars out of 5).  We also ordered a bread pudding muffin plus an egg + cheese sandwich on a bagel.  The bread pudding muffin was very good ...I don't necessarily believe that it was intended to be a breakfast item, but it worked!  They warmed it up and put a nice icing on it, delightful (4 stars).  As for the bagel sandwich, it wasn't mind-blowingly different than what you'd expect but was tasty nonetheless (3.5 stars).

We loved the cappuccinos and the friendly service.  I'd happily return to Henry's the next time I'm downtown looking for caffeine/breakfast.

Famished all day, I was on a mission to find a new place to eat, but something fairly close to home. I felt adventurous, but NOT that adventurous to go too far.

After living in the Tower Grove area for nearly 2 years, I finally decided to give Black Thorn a shot. All I've heard were good things minus the long wait people usually endure when coming here.

Jason and I got here around 7:30. To our surprise there was not a line nor was it insanely busy like we had anticipated. Another thing we had not anticipated was the set up of the place.

You have to place your order at the bar, get your own drinks from the bar, and pay all before you receive your pizza if you aren't going to keep an open tab. It basically has the same concept as a Bread Co. or Qdoba. Once you order, they'll bring you your pizza out.

We ordered a 12 inch Chicago style sausage and pepperoni pizza and a bowl of caesar salad to hold us over until the pizza came out. Little did we know that we were going to wait 30 minutes to receive the salad, then an additional 30 minutes after that for our pizza. As mentioned before, it was not busy. It had a few patrons, but not enough to cause the wait like we had to.

8:30pm. Pizza is out. We're ready and holy hot damn, am I excited! The pizza lived up to the hype I had hoped for. The time spent waiting was well worth every bite I ate. I think the only downside is the wait time. I don't know how long it takes to cook the pizzas. I'd assume awhile considering how thick the crusts are, but still, could they not have told us?

As far as the attitude of the bartender, I have to agree with Aimee K. The girl looked like she had a blank stare on her face, and she didn't seem too pleasant to talk to. I asked her when our salad was going to come out, and her reply was, "when we get to it." I went back to my seat and continued to wait without questioning. I didn't want anything to happen to our beloved deep dish pizza!

Anyway, aside from that, I like Black Thorn. The rustic looking 1980s dive bar setting who outlived its hay day truly adds character to this place. It has darts, hurling, and a juke box. You can't go wrong, especially in this hipster neighborhood.

Come check it out and you'll see what I mean.

I love running the tram road early in the morning or walking it at night-  In the evening I have spotted rattlers, tarantulas, toads.
To me every part of Sabino Canyon is beautiful- the desert is so amazing the beautiful cacti and deep red canyon walls. 
Haters will say its overrun and a tourist attraction- disagree.  If you get there early in the morning you avoid the tram all together.  Also if you have elderly family visiting or young children/children with disabilities  you will greatly appreciate the paved route.  And you can always get off the paved road onto a variety of trails. 
I like Sabino more than Mt. Lemon- 1. its a shorter drive, 2. it really feels like Tucson!

If you're really into food and dining out, Vetri is a must. Besides earning you foodie cred, it's an opportunity for a memorable evening. A special occasion is a good excuse to go, and the staff will make a big deal out of it which will add to the charm of it all.

When you're seated, take a sip of your complementary prosecco, take a deep breath, and relax. This is a 2-hour slow-paced tasting experience. The portions are tiny, but there are a lot of them.

Look over the menu to be sure you're not going to get something you know you'll hate or miss out on something you know you'll love. But don't spend too much time on this process. Keep an open mind because you might be surprised to love something that didn't sound appealing. 

The price is steep, yes. But you're paying for quality ingredients, impeccable service, and combinations of flavors more interesting than spaghetti and jarred sauce. It's important to remember that taste is subjective, and no one can guarantee that you absolutely love every single thing. If you expect to have visions of the Virgin Mary with every bite because you're dropping $$$$, and you'll be disappointed with anything less, you might as well stay home and order a pizza. 

And if the cost scares you, do what I did and save up your loose change for a couple of years. True story.

Came in for my 5-6 month prophy and saw Kara - who is a new hygenist and TERRIFIC.  She took text-book perfect bitewings (digital, baby!) and Dr. D is great as always. Plus I love LeeAnn (sp??) - the office manager.  Such a well-run place!

Plus I got strawberry prophy paste.

Wheeeeeee!

Love this hotel! I've travelled a lot (well, for a college student at least) and stayed in a lot of hotels, and this is the one I use as a benchmark to judge all other hotels by. I've stayed here many, many times.

Free breakfast buffet and drinks (which now include an option of coffee too, yay for us non-drinkers) if you're a Priority Club member. Bonus! And the buffet is really nice, it's not just a continental breakfast. It's got the fruit, cereal, yoghurt, etc., but there's also eggs, home fries, bacon, sausage, even make-your-own Belgian waffles!

There's free parking, too, and also a free shuttle that takes you within a few miles - it takes you downtown, that's the important thing. Plus it runs until 11 pm so you have plenty of time to do whatever you want and still catch the shuttle back, rather than rely on a cab. The WiFi is free as well and works pretty well. Nice and fast, it's only been sluggish when I'm there when a convention or some huge business thing is there.

The rooms are awesome! I like staying on the executive floor, though the rooms aren't any different on that floor so if you don't want to shell out the extra cash, you can just book a standard room. It's nice and clean (I've never had any problems with dirty carpets or dirty anything else). You get a balcony no matter what, with either a view of the Parthenon on the even numbered rooms, or the stadium on the odd numbered rooms. The bathrooms are great, too. All I'd change is some extra shelving in the shower area as there just isn't enough room in there to put much of anything. But I love the shower itself! Nice water pressure and temperature, and the shower head is awesome. And I love having a shower and not a shower/bath.

The pool is nice, too. It's outdoors so it's only open in the summer, but it's clean and big enough to accommodate everyone. If you wait to go in the evening, by then everyone will be leaving to go to dinner and you'll basically have the pool to yourself, if you don't want to deal with kids.

The only downside is the parking. They stay so busy all the time that it can be really hard to find a parking space here. Be prepared to walk! Tip: the handicapped spots fill up (even the ones in the back) so if you have problems walking distances, make sure you get to the hotel in the early afternoon to get a better spot, and just rely on the shuttle or cabs. There's always cabs hanging around too so you'll never have to wait for one. Another plus is if you have a hybrid or electric vehicle, they have two charging stations in the back of the hotel! I only just noticed it this time and don't drive one so I'm not sure what the pricing is, but if you need to charge your battery while staying there, you don't have to drive around finding a charging station.

It's just an all-around great hotel with a nice mixture of affordability and amenities.

We had a great time chowing down at this little Italian/pizza joint. Be warned that while all of my friends tried their pizza and loved it, I did not partake. Also, there is technically parking available, but it gets filled up super quickly, so be prepared to wait awkwardly if you come during busy dinner time.

As a large group, we pretty much ordered all of the appetizers, including greco salad, the broccolini caesar salad, the roasted bronzino, crispy artichokes, meatball, chicken parm, asparagus, octopus, short ribs, and a multitude of pizzas including margherita, eggplant, mushroom and zucchii and cipolla. while I can't speak much about the pizza, but heard great things about the cipolla, I really enjoyed the two salads, especially the broccolini and the spicy chicken parm. The asparagus and artichokes were a bit too over-oiled or fried for my taste. The short ribs were decent but just also a bit too fatty. The octopus was a tad bit on the chewy side and given how much it cost with how little were on the plate, I'd likely not get it in the future. I think if you want to eat frugally, the pizza and salad combination is likely the way to go, as the antipasti can add up, but overall, it's a decent, but expensive little Italian joint.

Food: 3-4 stars
Service: 3-4 stars
Price: 2-3 stars
Ambiance: 3 stars

Most choices were really great (avoid the chickenparm - awful.) like my crab-stuffed ravioli, over broccoli rabe.  St. Louis Ribs were fall-off-the bone tender.

There is a slight "SYSCO" pre-fab element to the food - but for the most part we love a nice weekend lunch here.  Burgers (patty melts, southwest style) are a solid choice.  Upgrading to Sweet potato fries is a good idea!

i love don pablo's for what it is - chain east coast tex-mex. as far as this genre goes, don pablo's blows its competition out of the water.

great starters (i highly recommend the border dip) and filling, tasty entrees. nothing is perfectly done, and not even close to authentically done, but it all tastes pretty good and the portions are extremely large relative to the price.

margaritas and domestic drafts seem to always be on special, if that's your thing. dos equis amber on draft is a plus for me, even though it's not a "special."

decor is corny and a bit forced, but family-friendly and very large and open, so the waits never get too long.

servers can be spotty, but for the most part are friendly, quick and attentive. i often go with my parents who tend to make borderline creepy remarks (my dad once asked our waiter if he was on facebook) and make tons of messes (same father spills an entire glass of diet coke every other visit), and they're good-natured about everything for the most part.

all in all, don pablo's is a surprisingly above-average dining option in the chain store wasteland that is south jersey.

Love going to trappings at Granite City. They have one every month,this month was the Burning Barn its a Irish Red very good. The bartender Jimmy dressed up like a leprechaun ( it was worth going just to see that) We played games bingo,count the jelly beans and also a drawing didn't win this time but there's always next time. Don't forget to sign up for there Mug Club Card next time your there.

I. LOVE. GELATO(& Frost).

My first gelato experience was at a Frost... not this location but I fell in love with the product. Being an "east-sider", when this location opened up, I was here weekly. It's that good. Now, I have come here whenever I am in town... the quality of the gelato has not changed, neither has the ambience of the store.

All the enticing flavors, with fruit, chocolate, and other goodies glare at me through the spotless glass case... all saying "pick me, pick me". I sample away then pick something I didn't sample...

Perfectly sized (3 to chose from), doesn't melt right away, and the flavors (cream or fruit based) are amazing!

I have only been here for one visit since I don't make it up to this area of town often, but this will certainly be high on my list of places to go when I am in the area. 

My visit came on a Friday night, and it was packed. Parking was made very easy in the free parking garage just go north on 1st Ave from Main St. (the intersection of Pint Room), and you will see the garage on your left immediately. There was a hostess that said she could seat us in the dining area of the place, or we could have a look around the open-seating bar area. We got really lucky and grabbed a table as another group was leaving, but trying to get a table in the bar area on a Friday night looked like a game of chance, as it was busy the entire time. There wasn't really a lot of standing room, so if you don't get a seat you might just want to put your name on the list for a table in the dining area.

I wasn't there to get food, which is good because it took me long enough just to decide on a drink from their enormous beer list. They have it broken down into categories of beers, and they cover the majority of the spectrum. The majority of their beers are on the safe side of things, but there are certainly some adventurous options on the list as well.  Don't quote me on this, but I am fairly certain that the beer list includes the name of the beer, the price, what state it is from, and the ABV %. It'd be nice to have an IBU rating, but even I will admit that I think that might be pretty ambitious for a list that long. I love that the price of every beer is listed by it. I'm amazed at how many places just have long beer lists without ever showing a price until you get your bill.

Our waitress did a great job relative to how busy it was. The guy who came over to clean our table after the last group left was not so much in that category. We got beers filled quickly and our waters stayed full the whole night. Our server even knew a decent amount about the beers they served and she was able to remind someone at our table what they had they last time they were there by just the description alone. One thing that is really frustrating at a place like this is when you finally make a decision on the one beer you want the most, and then they server goes to get it only to come back and say they are out and need a second choice. I know with a place that likes to rotate taps and gets in limited quantities of some beers that it happens, but the waitress didn't even take the time to cross it off of the beer list on our menus so the next person who sees that option and orders it will also be faced with coming up with a second option with no time to think. 

It was a little loud in here just due to the number of people, but it wasn't so bad that you couldn't have an easy conversation with the people at your table. The majority of the people here were young professionals, and the crowd was that of people who wanted to go out and get some drinks and dinner to catch up with friends, rather than to just go out drinking and getting wild for a night. There are quite a few TVs in the bar area, so all of the games you could want to watch will likely be viewable here, although it is much more of an upscale bar than a sports pub. As I said before, I wasn't here for food but everything I saw at surrounding tables looked delicious and I would like to give the food a try sometime, which I will likely be back to do in the summer when longer bike rides take me up to the Carmel area and I need a pit stop along the way.

Love the bar. Great Tequila selection, and better drinks. 

Food is great and creative. Seating upstairs is ok, downstairs is a different story. Get a seat at the bar if you're into the drinks, for there is no wait-service downstairs and the bar is smaller than my closet. So, unless you play Center for the Sixers, you're gonna wait to get a drink downstairs.

I recommend a 'flight' of Tequilas. Ask the bartender for advice if needed, they know what they're talking about here. 

Been here when its empty and bar is to ourselves, and on a busy Sat night..opt for the prior if you can. DJ sometimes (call ahead).

I have been a member here for years and I love having a standing monthly massage.
I had a regular therapist that I went to for several yeas but she left so now I am with another great therapist. Not everyone is as good as my two favorites but no one does a bad job.

I have never had any problems with the front desk staff either as others have indicated. 

I can't say I love the new chairs they have in the waiting room but that's a minor thing.

Thai food should be delicate, light and flavorful - and this is exactly what you can expect from Lanna Thai.  My BF and I came here late on a Tuesday night and we were the only ones in the restaurant.  Not wanting to keep them open later than they intended, we asked if it was too late to be served.  Without hesitation, the host insisted that we stay and enjoy a private dinner.  It was lovely!  We started with the spring rolls which were the freshest spring rolls I have ever had, most certainly rolled to order, and absolutely delicious!  We then ordered a papaya salad and two of their special dishes - a beef curry dish and a shrimp dish.  WOW.  Each dish was better than the next.  The shrimp were some of the largest I have enjoyed in Reno and the curry was perfectly balanced and unexpectedly light.  Amazingly, we polished off 3 beers and 4 dishes because everything was just that good!  I love thai food and this is most certainly my new favorite!

Have you tried Chick-Fil-A breakfast?  If you haven't you should go today!  I love this place for breakfast.  A chicken biscuit sounds a little odd at first but trust me they are great!  The employees are always very nice a chick Fill A too.

We loved the strawberry shortcake with whip cream and the strawberry pizza. It tasted so fresh and delicious. They didn't have much produce because they were closing down for the season. We really enjoyed the sweets! I would recommend it to anyone.

Sky Cafe has now become a regular Sunday outing and it is better every single time I go. Normally I love having a "secret" restaurant, but the whole experience of eating there is so positive that I just want everybody to have the opportunity to eat there and have the lovely family that owns it do well.

The noodle soups are absolutely to die for. I ate the barbecued pork noodle soup today (N4) because I had been thinking about it since LAST Sunday when I went there. The egg noodles are great and made in house. The vegetables are fresh. I eat the wontons last because they soak up the broth and are even better at the end than they were at the beginning. The coconut rice is a delicious side and has the perfect amount of sweetness to it. I tasted everyone else's meals as well (including a pork platter which comes with an absolute TON of food, and a coconut based chicken soup) and one thing was better than the next. The tea is great. Water is always full. Not to mention all of the food I just listed, a huge lunch for 3, came to a grand total of $19.

If the great food, atmosphere, and prices weren't enough - the family that owns it is completely fantastic. A brother and sister do the serving and know every single customer's name after only asking once (and in my case - they never asked at all, I just came in one day and they said "Hi Jessica"). They are warm and friendly and really make the restaurant.

Please, everyone go to Sky Cafe for a dining experience that is what you wish all dining experiences were like.

Perfect place to bring kiddos when the weather is yuck out!  I've never met a child that didn't know what Monkey Joe's is... Whether 2 years old or 6 years old - they ALL love it.

Staff is nice and the place is as clean as it can be with the amount of children running around and touching everything.

I was torn about whether to give this place one or two stars. Our dining experience was terrible terrible terrible, but you can't beat the location or the open air set up. It really is quite lovely to sit, quietly watching   Jackson Square by that ever-present flickering lamp light. And the interior of the restaurant is lush and lovely and oozes history. It would have been much nicer, of course, to enjoy these things while consuming, say, drinks, or food. After a certain point, I might even have settled for the smallest acknowledgment from any employee.

Sadly, that was not in the cards for us. I'll spare you the details but the gist is that we sat, totally ignored by all the staff, for far longer than is acceptable. Once we were noticed, we waited far too long for drinks and food. The service was terrible terrible terrible. 

The food (we both had red beans, rice, and sausage) was fine, though there was something slightly funky about the parsley garnish. Nothing outstanding, but I wasn't expecting outstanding. Given the size, location, and menu, I was betting on some adequate, tourist grade food, which is exactly what we got. 

So, ultimately two stars for the location, ambiance, and the fact that the food is not terrible. But there is not a chance in hell that I would go back. You can find something better.

Not happy with the changes to the menu. I miss the Choucroute Garnie and the escargots. I also loved having the option of ordering just the rillettes, but now you can only get the whole charcuterie plate.

Thank you Yelpers for a great meal, and about 10 pounds on the waistline. I love local spots that may not look like much from the front, but put their effort into great food. I followed instructions, read all the reviews, and ventured away from the airport hotels for this one, and you proved me right again.
As advertised, the owner was there preparing meals while her two helpers were the waiter and food prep staff. All three greeted me, told me about the specials, and then let me know which of the menu items they were sold out of...luckily, I am not a huge sauerkraut fan, so I did not miss out on its absence. One thing I was not informed of, but overheard at the end is that there is a tasting menu, which I made me almost eat a full second meal!
I had the stuffed cabbage, which was just perfect, good sauce, seasoned beef with rice and tender cabbage wrapped around it. I would almost call it a Bosnian Spring Roll! Other options could have been stuffed onions, grape leaves, or bell peppers.
The warm pita bread had a nice herb baste and delicious flavour, especially when mixed with the cucumber sauce. 
Then, without further ado... you MUST save room for dessert. Have a Bosnian coffee and the baklava. Best. Baklava. Ever.

Review is just for minigolf - my daughter loves minigolf and always wants to try a new place. Greattimes is right next to 465, so it has never looked too appealing to me. We tried it on a recent weekend and the minigolf turns out to be pretty nice! They offer 36 holes and you can play either 18 or all 36.

Minigolf is well maintained, carpeted concrete with a paving stone border and some cast rock obstacles. The surface is not flat, there are rolling "hills" and various ups, downs, and sideways breaks on the putting surface.

There is a fair number of trees, so a decent amount of shade. There's well maintained grass, water features, fountains, lots of decor. We will be back

The Tower Grove Farmers Market is quite possibly the best in the area.  Live music, a lot of vendors (30+ usually), free yoga (not my thing, but lot's of people like it), such an eclectic gathering of people, and you just gotta love Tower Grove Park.

I am a bit disappointed to see people complaining about it being expensive.  Yes, it actually costs a lot of money to produce things, much less make a living off of it.  And you pay more for quality.  If you can't tell the difference between produce here and the produce at the grocery store, then please have your taste buds checked. [communist] I have zero problem paying more to support small farmers and small business over a faceless conglomerate that primarly profits from being cheap and from exploitation [/communist].

Anyway, I love the atmosphere here and it just a great community gathering spot.  Sometimes it's more fun to people watch than actually shop.  If you have kids, there is a nearby wading pool and playground, and there are always tons of kids around.

To top it off, the owners update their website and facebook every week to let you know what will be fresh and for sale the upcoming weekend.  And they also have recently started a farmers market downtown, which shows a major commitment to the community.  If you need a reason to get your ass out of bed before noon on Saturday, this is it.

Fun little event tonight....dampened the outdoor vendors but inside this place is full of original, eccentric, unique stuff! I thought the store name was adorable anyway, but I loved the local artists' work, and all of the wonderful smelling soaps and candles. Their check in deal included a free soy candle tonight which I loved. I chose the lemongrass scent and can't wait to burn it at home. They have an area to create your own massage oil, lotion, and seas salts with essential oils. Had a mini-reiki session with a lady they call Tattooed Nana which was interesting and different. I'm probably missing something but there's so much packed into this little place! I'll be back for milk paint, and hopefully to score some original accents for my home. Thanks for the margaritas tonight ladies!

I will definitely go back and explore the menu more and hopefully can then move to a 4* where it probably should be.  The bar was set very high as I heard lots of great buzz about Nox but on this visit it missed just a little for me. 

The service was best part of the night, top notch staff, server was very professional, responsive and on his game.  The staffs attire, friendliness, demeanor, etc. all are a perfect compliment to the concept and enhance the experience.    

We started with the poblano soup and although it had a great flavor it wasn't at the appropriate serving temperature, it came out tepid, lukewarm.  And the soup was served fast so its not like it was sitting around waiting to be served.  Miss. 

For entrees the wife got the salmon and I had the burger.  I wasn't totally in the mood for a burger but In my opinion when a burger is on the menu at a place like this you expect it to be amazing but it fell flat for me. It was overcooked, (ordered medium rare) and it was almost well done.  It had good flavors and I am sure it would have been better had it came out medium-medium rare. Bacon and cheese were nothing special and the pretzel bun was too dry and I tossed it after a couple bites.  I also can't eat much, bun and all, so that is probably on me as burger probably eats better with the bun on every bite.  The fries were good but nothing special.  Had to ask for an aioli to fun it up and the chipotle aioli was tasty.

The wife's salmon was tasty, loved the chili flavors and brussel sprouts, different enough from the usual salmon dish so that one scored big.  Was a little overcooked though. Was too full for desert but maybe next time.

A suggestion on a way they could improve upon the experience is making better use of the space and decor in the back.  The place has a great ambiance when you walk in but it loses everything in the back where we were seated. I would like to see better decor in the back and you have to do something with that big empty space in the middle.  I know its a weird shape back there but need to get some fung shway going. Our table was against the wall and then next to us a huge empty space with visibility into all the server areas.  And a big plant that the servers bumped into every time they went back there. There is also a a very awkward 2 top in the corner along the bench seating.  

I am picturing consolidating the server stations to one in the very back and putting in two big butchers block tables and seat family style.  And/or wrap the bar around and create some fun seating out of that like a breakfast bar/nook with just one butcher block.  

I think the decision makers could get some great ideas from this place http://holeman-finch.com/ it reminded me of what Nox could be.  Same deal they are in a strip mall with a weird shaped space.  It would seriously be worth a quick trip to Atlanta to check it out and have a great dining experience while there.  With a few tweaks like holeman and finch Nox could be a home run.

This is one place that should not be over looked when out shopping. They have just about everything you need and more. I love the ample selection of food and have to ignore most of it when I walk through the store. They have a great assortment of electronics, automotive, and housewares. No shortage of kids toys and knick knacks for the inside and outside of your place. I find that I can get some things cheaper here than at the much larger box stores for half the price also.

Expensive drinks should have a good amount of alcohol in them and my clover clubs were perfectly done but my husband's second Moscow Mule seemed to just be ginger beer with no vodka...disappointing especially when the 1st one was perfect. I did like the two hidden rooms which made it feel less like just chilling in a hotel lobby.

Love at 425 degrees!  We decided to have pizza last night and to take advantage of their $10 for any large pizza deal.  We got the Murphy's combo minus olives.  The gal that took my order was friendly and efficient, though she quoted my total due incorrectly twice, but it was funnier than bothersome.  She told me that the pizza would be ready within 5 minutes.  I took a seat and before the seat was warm my name was being called to pickup the pizza.  I cooked the pie for 14 minutes (recommended is 12-18), which cooked it perfectly.  There were plenty of toppings, cheese and a nice golden brown crust.  The only knock on the pie was the sauce, which had issues with consistency of spices.  Of the few slices that we had, we would occasional get a heavy dose of Italian spices.  I love spice in my sauce, but it was a bit overwhelming.  We will go back for the deal, as there isn't a better pizza deal in town, when you just want something quick to make at home.

Burger Up was more like Burger Ok.  I like the atmosphere and the service, but I wasn't amazed by the food, it was ok at best.  

The atmosphere is rustic/modern.  I love the big huge chalkboard talking about what farms they source for food.  Very cool in my book.  The service was great.  The hostess was awesome with her greeting and our server Leah was pretty nice.

Now the food could use a little improvement.  I got the black bean and quinoa burger with the sweet potato fries.  The fries were soggy and at a lukewarm temperature.  My friend's truffle fries were of the same quality as far as temperature and texture go.  The burger was also a little on the lukewarm side too, not hot at all.  My friends did not oh and awe over their burgers either.  

I might be back for lunch at the least, but as for now, not my top choice.

So many good things to say about Beawon - they're such a pleasant atmosphere of friendly servers, inviting (and well-lit) dining room and their FOOD.  

Bon chons --- awesome!  The different kinds we had were some sort of potato salad, kimchi (of course), fishcake & a few others that are currently slipping my mind.  Loved 'em all & they were quite nice about refilling for seconds :).

I tip-toed past my usual kalbi & soondubu favorites and ventured on instead for some kkanpunggi (a spicy version of sweet & sour chicken) & Jjamppong, a sort of ramen-type dish with seafood.  I really liked the jjamppong, but preferred the broth tossed with rice instead of noodles (perhaps this is a change they could make for you per request?).  Happily slurped up all the goodness, seafood was really fresh, couldn't have asked for a better heart-warming meal.

The prices alone bump this up to 4 stars! The lunch special is crazy, a soup and app, plus entree only $9! The coconut soup and corn/shrimp cakes were great, I also really liked my masam curry. The tilapia tasted a bit off due to the fried dough it was in. Chicken teriayaki dish was pretty good. I didn't really love the pad see ew, it wasn't as sweet as I usually like it. Overall this is definitely worth checking out for some affordable thai food!

square peg definitely has yelp to thank for the $200+ i dropped there yesterday (not all on presents for me, sheesh!). until a few days ago, i had never heard of the shop but i saw them mentioned in the most recent weekly yelp round-up. i was instantly intrigued and a bit...embarrassed maybe (rueful? regretful?)? as a kid growing up in philly i knew all the cool shopping spots, but as i got older (and busier) so much cool shit just doesn't hit my radar....

but thankfully, places like square peg get the attention they deserve. it took be about ten minutes to get past the first six feet of the shop. i wanted to touch (and buy) everything i saw and was barely successful in buying more for those on my shopping list than i was for myself. i am not going to list my specific purchases (since the recipients may read this review), but to give you an idea of what the shop has....leather cuffs, awesome jewelry (including fresh fruit earrings. intrigued? go check em out. :D and cool pendants, buttons and bracelets/necklaces), small crafted keepsakes and magnets, knitted bits of prettiness, pleasantly pungent soy candles (i have never smelled candles this fragrant, in a good way for sure. and yes, the alliteration is a oblique reference to penny pingleton is permanently punished in case you were wondering...), bags/purses, baby onesies and assorted prints....i am sure there are tons of other perfect presents there, and i was able to finish up two people on my list and make headway on a third (and find something a little extra for my sister). i LOVE places like this, perfect for presents and goodies (or when you want to indulge yourself).....thank you yelp for the word.....

So a vegetarian walks into a meat-centric restaurant... and a four star review ensues? Yep, that's right. I like The Block a lot! Everything I've had here has been good. I've been a handful of times. The only thing I wish they had was one more vegetarian entree on the menu for variety. 

I love the happy hour here. Great drinks and food specials. My favorites are the fries and the soft pretzels with cheese sauce. Both delicious!! 

For lunch or dinner, their salads are great. They always have a special salad and it doesn't always include meat, but if so, they can modify it. Their salad dressings are great and ingredients really fresh. Half or whole portions are available for all appetites. Their mac n cheese is a good option but it was missing something to make it a little more flavorful. I loved the cheese on top. 

They have house made desserts, which are amazing!! Their homemade ice cream is to die for. Really. Don't miss it. 

Service is always good. 

I'll be back!

I haven't actually had a meal here yet, but I popped in for a few desserts this week, and everything was amazing! 
I took home a slice of strawberry cake, vanilla cheesecake, and a lemon bar. 
The triple layer strawberry cake was so beautiful, and big enough to share. My daughter loved it. I'm not a big icing fan, but she loved the cream cheese frosting and I loved the bite of cake she let me steal. 
The vanilla cheesecake was also a hit with my other daughter, but she thought it might have needed to be left out of the fridge a bit longer before serving. 
I had the lemon bar, which was the best I've ever had, with fresh lemon curd and a nice and crisp shortbread crust. I will have a hard time not stopping in for these every time I drive past! 
The proprietor served me, and was perfectly lovely. It's worth noting that she has excellent taste in food, beer, and wine. For such a limited menu the shop has a really amazing local beer and (not local ) wine selection. I was impressed. 
I can't wait to stop by for breakfast or lunch. They're not open for dinner, so go early! They close at 6.

I stopped by with my family on a Sunday afternoon--middle of the day.  Perfect time to go if you don't want to wait for a table.  I really liked the casual atmosphere.

We were greeted right away and our server was quick to bring us our drinks.  I went with the Bear Creek Farm Classic Burger and a side salad to be just a wee bit healthy.  The burger was awesome.  I usually don't finish burgers but this one went down fast.  I tried some of the sweet potato fries that a family member got.  I can't say that I loved them.  The taste was good but the texture...not so much.  Too limp and undercooked for my taste.

But I did not go to Burger Up for the fries.  I went for a burger and will definitely be back.

I finally made it back for a "regular" visit. The last time I was here was for the Elite dinner and I gave it a 5 star review. Today I was not as satisfied with the service or the food. 

I arrived around 2pm to meet a friend for some lunch. I believe the hostess saw us, but we actually had to ask her for a table. We were not greeted at all. We did have the option to sit on the patio and so we decided to do that; we both love patios! The hostess brought us to a table, placed the menus down, told us about brunch (which runs until 3pm on Sundays), and walked away. I didn't get the sense that she wanted to be there. A few minutes passed by and no one came to our table...then a few more minutes passed and finally a guy showed up to take our drink order; he was not going to be our server though. Our drinks came out and our server showed up. He was friendly once he arrived so things got better. 

We placed our orders ordered some beer and waited for our food. The food arrived in a good amount of time. I was a little disappointed in my meal and I know my friend was as well. I'll start with my order; goat cheese and strawberry salad with grilled chicken. The salad looked like it was drenched in salad dressing. I completely forgot to ask for my dressing on the side and didn't want to send it back. I like dressing so it was ok, but not everyone is like me and that amount of dressing may have been discouraged another customer. The chicken was really tough and dry! For a grilled chicken I was expecting it to me juicy and flavorful; it wasn't. I was disappointed in the overall salad. My friend ordered the steak salad; medium well. When the salad was brought out she too complained about the amount of dressing; maybe we both should have ordered the dressing on the side? Oh, and her steak she said was tough and more like well done. The kitchen missed the ball on this one. I don't think we will recommend the salads in the future. For the prices of the salads I know we were both expecting something better! Each salad was about $15! Whoa! 

Our server did offer bread and was attentive throughout the meal, so he gets some major Kudos! Good job Mike! I just think the kitchen has some work to do. The food has potential if it is done correctly.

I love this Farmer's Market, mostly because I love Companion bakery (especially their brioche, perfect for bread pudding, french toast, sandwiches, etc)!
I also love Bittersweet Bakery that is always there... And Tower Grove Park in general is such a lovely setting for a farmer's market...

I generally don't buy any of the fruits and veggies, just because they're a bit out of my price range, but it's a fun place to check out and take photos at.

Also, there's a fountain nearby with tons of kids running through it which just makes the place cuter.

I like bringing visiting foodie friends here and they always love it too.... We always grab a snack and/or coffee... it's a pleasant atmosphere with lots of crisp white stalls with bright colored fresh fruits and veggies!

I love how I'm going to be that chick that reviews all the Enterprise Rent-A-Car. I can't be the only Yelper who doesn't have a car, right?! It's Philly!

Right now I'm a fan of Enterprise. I can hear you scoffing, but $9.99 weekends are heaven for me. I can rent a car for the whole weekend and do all the things I want to do like .... go car shopping so I can stop coming to freakin' Enterprise.  

The best part of the $9.99 weekends is that even if the Enterprise close to you isn't participating, you can RETURN the car at any Enterprise location. Awesome. So I returned mine here and this branch was nicer than the one I rented it from. It was warm, smelled clean, and didn't look depressing at all. The guy was a little too enthusiastic for a Monday morning. I think he saw me check-in on Yelp! because he held out his hand and was like "Please tell me you're a satisfied customer and we did everything we could for you today!" in this fake boisterous robotic voice. Scared the s*** out of me. Almost docked them one star for the ass-kissing, but realized quickly, it could have been worse. He could have "kept it real" and treated me like ass because it's early on a Monday morning, but he didn't. He put on his best fake smile. And you know what? Thanks guy. Firm handshake back!

I love Tijuana Flats!! They have the best sauce and best TACOS!! I go just about every Tuesday for Tacos because you cannot beat the deals. The food fits a college kids budget and is super fresh, what more could you ask for. I reccommend this for anyone hungry and not looking to spend a lot on a Tuesday.

How have I not reviewed the Range yet? 

One of the few "Bailey's" restaurants you'll find around STL. The biggest thing I love about these places is the "Farm-to-table" food. Menus revolving around the season, locally sourced meats for the burgers, and heck, even the tap beer selection is local! I enjoy the selection of unique beef, bison or even goat burgers, as well as trying the variety of dipping sauces for your fries. You feel like you are dining in a cleaned up barn while here...and I mean that in a good way. The decor appears to have been salvaged parts of farm houses and barns.
