Adding to the home on the range feeling and something I've never seen anywhere else (other than an Amish family restaurant) is the long "family-style" table running through the middle of the building. It encourages sitting next to strangers and making new friends! I love it. 

Before arriving, they do not take reservations, so don't bother. Also, parking is on the street if you can find a spot. Otherwise there are plenty of lots and garages within walking distance.

Enjoy!

First, I have a wet butt. Why because the first booth we sat in was wet. I look up and see a moldy vent dripping water. We go to the next booth and it was better. Although I don't think the floor has been swept in a while. So, the food was meh. Really meh. The eggs were not scrambled soft as we ordered. So, we didn't eat them. My daughter ordered Mac and cheese. It was thin and watery with a bread crumb topping. Tasted like a box meal. Then I ordered a sampler which comes with coffee and juice. She brings me a large juice. When I get the bill, I have a charge for a coffee and juice. The manager says, you got a large juice so I'll just give you an adjustment. No, you'll give me what I ordered. I didn't ask for a large. I asked for a juice with my sampler. I've never been here before and won't be back. How would I know this? She says if it's really a big deal for you I'll just take it off. No, it's not that it's a big deal for me. Doing what's right and not nickel and diming me is important. Hell, I'm still hungry. The fact you cleared our plates and two of us left 80% of our food on the plate should tell you something. The coffee was never hot. The pancakes were microwaved. And, so was the Mac and cheese. I only ate my bacon. My daughter had a club sandwich. We probably all should have went with the sandwich. My home fries were gross. I don't think they use seasonings at all in anything. Yuck! Yuck! Yuck! Love supporting mom and pop places but if your food sucks, your service should shine.

The location is fantastic. Just far enough removed from the mess of Bourbon Street, but still close enough for you party people. Pretty much everything is within walking distance - even the conference center on the river front is only a 20 minute walk away. 

I enjoyed my stay here, and really appreciated the fact that they let me check-in at 8AM on the morning of my arrival even though check-in time is typically not until 4PM. I also loved the room that I was given (a corner room on one of the newly added floors). It was spacious and the bed was so, so comfortable. It was like sleeping on clouds, I kid you not. The only thing that kind of irked me was the separate elevator that was needed to access the top 3 floors - it made the whole commute up and down the building quite a hassle. 

All in all, I would highly recommend this Wyndham for either business or pleasure. They make things very convenient for you - with cab pickups, printing services at the front desk, etc.

I was here for my birthday party with 12 other guests. Karen was our waitress and she was just so wonderful. Carusos has never disappointed me. I love the ambiance, the lasagna al forno is the best, their salads are so delicious, their Italian dressing is unique. But this special time on this special day, Karen was on top of everything at my table. She was fast and caring and made sure everyone got their food. Nothing was wrong with anyone's order, she even set up my birthday cake really nice. I couldn't be thankful enough for her and for the background employees at Caruso's. I've been eating here since I was 5 years old. This is a true classic, delicious Italian restaurant and I will always recommend to friends and family.

Made it to Luke's for dinner and the crabmeat ravioli is AMAZING.  However I'm knocking off a star because the place was a zoo.  

The next table was a 50th birthday party of 9 adults; one of the women was literally yelling at the top of her voice.  With tile/hardwood floors and tin ceilings, the volume in the restaurant almost ruined our meal.  It was exceedingly difficult to carry on a conversation at our table of 5 in between the shrieks next to us.  

Other dishes at our table were the redfish (w/ the crabmeat), the vanilla duck, shrimp & grits, and the shrimp farci.  Everyone thought their food was lovely...if only the atmosphere had been as nice.

4.5 stars - I am rounding up for this place.
Damn this place is good.
Marketing that I have never seen to sell wine- offering a food pairing FREE with a bottle. Nice work Terra Sur.
So we enjoyed a bottle of cab paired with manchego, chorizo and olives (forgot to ask price, $62...yikes) have t say the wine paired with all our food. Great pic on our part 
Apps- taquenos y yucitas- the little balls or potato n cheese with the dipping sauce was yummy; the wonton stuffed with mozzarella was ok- a bit greasy and heart-attacky for me tonight. Hubby polished them off!  
Ceviche- tried the ceviche creama de Rocoto - holy smokes, so do good! Tender calamari, sweet potato and little corn things to offset the spice, wow! Try this!
Dinner- Tacu y Tacu which was similar to con con (in the Dominican world) crispy rice but this was mixed with white beans, topped with Lomo saltedo great texture, taste and the steak was tender. I can eat this daily.
Tips- portions are HUGE, share a dinner unless you love to gorge yourself or unless you plan for leftovers! 
I can't wait to go back
Love this place

I am not sure why Ru San's has such bad ratings on Yelp. I guess it really depends on a variety of things, including the day you went in, how parking was that day, how your service was, and who was the chef that day. 

Either way, we have been to Ru San's twice and used Groupons both times and loved our experience. I am not sure if I would return here for a full priced meal just because Nashville has so many options, and some of them cheaper than Ru San's but for half-priced these guys were great. 

We loved their appetizers, especially the avocado-shrimp nacho looking thing (I cannot for the life of me remember it's name). We also really enjoyed their calamari. 

The sushi is great. They have a lot of friend options and regular sushi options. Their speciality rolls are good too. 

We have never run into a problem with their service. The first time we went there, we were in and out in a matter of 1-1.5 hours. The second time, we were using a Groupon and usually you cannot use it for alcohol but the waiter let my boyfriend use it for his beer anyway. That was cool of him!:) 

TIP: I would park with the valet at Sambuca. It is the easiest way to find parking at the Gulch and worth the dollar tip.

Being a clean eater that strays away from meat and gluten makes it a little difficult to go out to eat. Finding someone to dine with at a vegetarian restaurant can be difficult so I often find myself saying "I'll just get a salad" when going out to eat with friends. At Blue Sage there were many options for me and I couldn't have been more pleased.

Before I get to the food I would first like to compliment our server, Charlee. She was very kind and well educated on the menu. This is important because I can't eat gluten and get very nervous when dining at a restaurant for the first time. She made my first experience at Blue Sage fantastic!!

For starters, she offered a delicious UNSWEETENED raspberry iced tea, which is almost impossible to find! We also got an appetizer, the Tacos Verduras. The amount of texture and flavor piled high on a homemade blue corn taco was more than satisfying. I split this with a friend but was tempted to put in another order as my meal. 

Instead of doing that I went for the miso pumpkin soup. The miso broth was jam packed with flavor and even developed a slight creamy texture. The soup was hearty and had medium, bite sized chunks of cauliflower and pumpkin which was accompanied but the punch of flavor possessed by scallions. I was In love. 


Overall, I was extremely satisfied with the service, flavor, portions and prices. I am so excited to go back to Blue Sage and try more of their menu!

I love idea of this place. So nicely decorated and themed, but it is sooo over priced in my opinion. 12.50 for a slice of cake and most of the drinks start at 11+ dollars. The cake is pretty good, some better than others. Overall taste from the ones I've tried I'd would give 7/10, but maybe I just had higher expectations due to price. 

However there is nothing else quite like It when you are celebrating something special. When we came it was very hot outside so we sat inside, it was just as hot if not hotter. Not sure if they have a/c there or not but to spend that kind of $$ and be uncomfortable was a bit disappointing, and had to cut my date with my friend short due to it.

The drinks are as tasty as they look/sound but again with what you get for for the price? 5/10

I love this Morning Call. I was so happy when I heard they were keeping this location open. My routine as of late is to come here for a nightcap after a fun night out on the town. Nothing else quite hits the spot like hot beignets and a cafe au lait. I love these beignets in particular because they are so fluffy and have those lovely air pockets when you bite into them. 

I enjoy the nostalgia of Morning Call and if you forget how long they have been around just look at their cash register because George Washington could have used it by the looks of it. 

No matter what time of day or night it is, its always hustling and bustling with customers. Its loud and its perfect.

Even though I also have two dogs and a wonderful general veterinarian, I take our cat specifically to St. Louis Cat Clinic. The reviews by Rhonda S. and Saskia S. are 100% accurate. The doctors at SLCC are wonderful wonderful wonderful. 

I've had three of our cats as patients here and can't dream of taking them anywhere else. The staff is so friendly and help to calm down our Mickey once we arrive after his traumatic car ride. (NOT a fan of the car.) 

The care and individual attention is always topnotch. You will never feel as though your cat is "just another" chart and patient for them to deal with. 

Another great perk? There are resident-house cats that are always there roaming the lobby and halls. T-Rex has become our little friend and now any time I go to pick up food, my BF comes along just to get in his face time with Mr. T-Rex. Loves him!

My husband and I had a late lunch/early dinner at ML Rose the other day. I'd never been to the West location, and I have to say, it's great! Easy to get to off the freeway and lots of available parking. It's much easier to find seating inside too than the original location, probably because it's larger. 

You cannot beat the beer selection they offer. It's just hands down one of the best available in Nashville. I tried my first Sour Beer here on this visit, and after looking around online, found it was one of the more popular ones on the "beer market" :) right now. So glad they had it because I am in love!

We both enjoyed burgers for dinner; I had the five alarm which is the perfect blend of spicy and cheesy and juicy, and my husband had the bacon cheeseburger. I upgraded to the sweet potato fries - holy crap! They were crispy and sweet, and our server was awesome enough to bring me a side of the Carolina BBQ sauce for dipping (this was so good - do it!).

We'll be back to this location for sure. Love ML Rose!

My only complaint here is always the temperature of the building. It always seems stuffy and warm, no matter what time of year we go. Other than that we thoroughly enjoyed the new Reel West Exhibit, contemporary art, and especially all of the Native American paintings. I love the old art-o-matic machine on the second floor, next to the elevator. It's an old cigarette machine that for $5 you can pull a knob and it will dispense the art of your choice. I chose the silver or gold plated earrings knob and got a cute pair of dangly  sterling silver earrings designed by an artist!!! Other options were necklaces, watercolor painting, some kind of fortune cookie and many more. All in all, it was a great way to spend the day with my family. The lower level is an interactive play and learning area, fun for kids and adults. Also if you park in the underground garage you can get validation for parking at the ticket counter so that parking is free, so don't let parking prices posted deter you from visiting!!!

This is very laid back, relaxed and fun spot for a Nashville show. The sound quality isn't the very best, and it can be down right bad depending on where you're standing. And it's all standing, which is sometimes tough for this old broad. I love the new little attached bar though - great place to relax, chat, and yes I'm old, sit before a show. Good prices and I like the mobile ticketing through ticketfly.

I wanted to love this place. I've passed by for years while wandering South Street, always keeping in mind that there's a cute, convenient little place that solely sells bibimbap. Finally took the plunge one day and went to order the 'bap. 

I've had my fair share of Korean rice in stone pots that have warmed my soul and whet my appetite. This came to me in a large aluminum bowl to accentuate the size of the meal. I wasn't completely wowed even knowing full well the guy prepared it just there and then. Good assortment of veggies, rice, meat but definitely echo some of the other reviewers here - it just wasn't enough. Typically bibimbap makes me keel over from sheer amazingness; quality and quantity and delicious. This gave me more of an: it's alright, feels sufficient. Lots of options for similar prices on South Street and surrounding area but if you want 'bap quick and easy, it can be an easy fix for you.

I really like this place.

My latte was excellent.  It had just the right amount of espresso "bite" without being harsh or too acidic.  The temp was spot-on as well - very nice.

Food wise, I've only been here for breakfast, and it's very good.  I suggest you try "The Lovely," which is a grits dish loaded up with unhealthy goodness - thick bacon, chunks of cheddar, and a fried-egg on top.  The grits themselves seem overcooked and a bit too creamy to me, but their menu does describe them as "slow cooked," so I assume this finish is intentional.  I like my grits a bit, well, grittier.

Beyond the grits, they have lots of other breakfast foods, including some good sandwiches with sausage, eggs, etc.

It's a big cafe, with plenty of tables, large and small.  The staff seems to support the fact that lots of people like to settle in and hang out a while.  This gives a good cafe a pub feel, and Edgehill has a good bit of this.

If you've not been here, check it out and let us all know what you think.

So I got the MEMO about the 50 cents oyster @ Happy Hour...and during our visit to NOLA...we were so eager to go to eat as many oysters possible at a steal deal price!

Arrived around 4ish on a HOT (week)day. We both were tourists..wearing shorts, t-shirts and sandals just like MOST others in the bar (happy) hour area. The hostess was friendly but the waiter was just a plain @$$ ...pardon my language here.

Yup, we got the head to toe look and he walked around and talked to us with his nose pointing to the ceiling, oh, come on!! We didn't care really... all we wanted were just some fresh oysters and great beer to wash away the heat.

We ordered a dozen of the oysters and the duck liver and rabbit pate $8 with two glasses of beer (we later got a second round of beer).

The oysters came out slowly.. we almost finished our beer when they arrived. They looked grossed and not cleaned well. I understand it was 50 cents each..but they shouldn't cut corners on cleanliness especially while serving raw food plus they are a fancy restaurant..how do you expect us to come back for the pricier dinner if you can't even clean the oysters well?

We were thinking to order a couple more dozens but the fact that we tasted the debris from the oyster shucking process in each oyster PLUS the unappetizing look of the small shells sticking on the oyster' shells.. we just got turned off!

The pate was excellent and we loved the pickled cucumber etc and the warm toasted bruchetta that came with it and $8 was certainly worth the priced. We licked it clean!!

We were planning to go to Luke for a couple times during our NOLA visit and even considered going there for dinner (we watch food network and top chef masters) BUT our not-so-great first (and only) happy hour experience @ Luke left none to desire to come back.

Our total tab including tax and tip was about $40... they get you on the alcohol..

The pate is a 4 to 5 stars..the oyster price is also a 5 stars, BUT the snotty service and lack of cleanliness didn't make the cut..so I'm giving Luke a fair 3 stars.

This place is awesome. It's right on the pier and it's not a fancy schmansy type of seafood restaurant which I love. I hate hate hate touching my food without utensils so when I go to a seafood place, I want to go to one where I can get dirty and not feel judged.  My boyfriend and I got a whole crab and whole lobster.  They came with some sides and with two drinks it came out to be about $95, which is decent for the size of our fresh, steamed crustaceans.  The menu/prices are written on the chalkboards above the bar area.  The atmosphere was great and the service was good. I would definitely come back and recommend to others.

Face it, people -- you don't go to IHOP for gourmet or ambiance, you go for a heaping stack of good old carbs! And do carbs ever disappoint? Personally, not at IHOP. It's one of my top 5 places for comfort food. Just gimme a big stack of those old-fashioned buttermilk pancakes and lay on the syrup! Yeah, I'm an easy girl to please, but don't tell anyone else that.

I have and always will love pancakes. And I always used to lament that Edmonton paled in comparison to Vancouver (Burnaby specifically) because we did not have an IHOP. (There's something odd when you don't much care about the ocean and the mountains but more for pancakes) So when the fiance and I were driving back from the airport one night on Calgary Trail, I gasped and found myself literally unable to speak after seeing the billboard announcing that IHOP was finally coming to Edmonton. My fiance was freaked out of his mind, as he thought there was something wrong as he was driving.

No matter what time of day it is, morning, noon or evening, I will exercise my right to have pancakes. So naturally, my first meal here was a dinner of pancakes. That's normal enough, right? If you're a fellow pancake-lover and have a sweet tooth, I recommend getting the Tooti-Fruiti (I'm so not making that name up), which comes with strawberry pieces and strawberry sauce drizzled on top. If your sugar tastebuds don't rule your mouth, go for a combination instead. You can choose your type of pancakes and throw them together with the classic side choices of bacon, sausage links, eggs, or hashbrowns. I'm going to be honest and admit their scrambled eggs are not so great --they're pretty much some kinda pre-mixed egg liquid they pour into the frying pan and stir up, i.e. not fresh.

But you don't go to IHOP for the eggs! You go for the pancakes ... they're not called The International House of Pancakes for nothing! If you plan on going, avoid Sunday afternoons as it is mayhem. We attempted going one Sunday around 1:30 PM and the waiting area was packed. One woman walked out muttering, "It's not worth it." So be forewarned! But have fun, stuff your face, and get your pancakes on :)

Love their chicken strips! I have only ordered takeout, so I can't comment on the atmosphere much, but the strips and fries are delicious. Nice crispy chicken, always ready on time. $15 for a 6 piece, but it's enough to feed both me and my husband. 

They will only include sauce if you ask for it. Their signature is a sweet and hot sauce. Its good!

Pancake Pantry is one of those restaurants that your family considers its own. The one you know you'll be eating at on vacation, every time you visit that city/town. The kind of homey, nostalgic place that you elevate to greatness in your mind and speak of with reverence.

The fluffy pancakes, in what seem to be a gazillion forms, are the main attraction. I love the blueberry variety with its warm, fruit compote. I'm also a fan of a Frankenstein creation which involves breakfast potatoes (not hashed browns), veggies, multiple cheeses, ham (which I sub for mushrooms), and two eggs. A meal that lasts most of the day into early evening. My mom's new obsession is the banana walnut cakes which she says taste like banana bread in pancake shape.

Prices are reasonable for the large portion size and service is very prompt. They want to get you in and out with a smile so the line can keep moving right up until their afternoon closing time. I've never left hungry and never needed to have to much after a breakfast here.

Having said that, the Pantry (we use one name after all these years) isn't perfect. Parking in Hillsboro Village is challenging - it's right in the middle of a busy hub of shops, restaurants, hospitals, and Vanderbilt. The wait can be obnoxious - on this last trip we stood (yes, stood, they do it old school here) in line for over an hour on a Friday at 11 am. However, neither of these things has ever deterred us from going. It must be love!

I'm sorry there are so many bad reviews for this place, because my experience was just fine.  But there may be a disclaimer, I came on a very rainy day and we were practically the only customers, so there was plenty of clean seating and service was nice and fast!  I ordered the ginger chicken and broccoli with brown rice.  The rice was very plain but I thought the ginger sauce was yummy and the broccoli was very good.  Nice huge crispy chunks.  The chicken was also tender and well made.  Not tough or chewy or any mystery bites like you get at sketchy Chinese places.  I used the red pepper spicy sauce that they provide at the condiment counter, I love that stuff, gave my food a nice kick.  I went in not expecting much considering the whole Chinese chain ordeal, but I had a good experience.  Fast service and hot yummy food.

I love the layout of this place.  There's a typical pizza shop on one side to pick up something quick and a restaurant side if you're looking for waiter service.  The food is good with no items that stand out.  Most of the cheesesteak/hoagies are around $6 - $7, with a $1.75 drink, you gotta meal for under $10.

One plus, BEER!  They have an ok selection of 6-packs.

What a gem!!!!! I love a good shrimp taco!!! These are definitely an authentic shrimp taco. Im usually not a huge fan of corn tortillas but these were actually very good!!!! I love how you can select your own toppings and the pickled onions were such a good choice. The jamaica was good too. Staff was very friendly as well. If I lived in Philly this would be my good to place

We are so lucky and spoiled to have an awesome Children's Museum in Indy.  Sometimes I take it for granted, but this is an awesome place for children (and adults!) of all ages.  They have a nice amount of rotating exhibits to mix it up so that you and your kids don't get bored.

I bring my one year old niece here and she can find things that are fun for her.  They playscape room for babies and toddlers is great because they can play and explore in a safe place away from older kids.  She loves playing in the sand and making music.  I have a good time here too because most of the exhibits are interesting for kids and adults.

Come the first Thursday of the month between 4-8 and get your tickets for 5 bucks!  It's pretty busy, but worth it due to the drastically reduced cost!

They never disappoint! I didn't realize how much I've missed BR! I had forgotten they were still around and pretty much went to Creole Creamery for ice cream. 
I love the Pralines and Cream and the Bananas Foster! They now have a flavor of the month. It was a salted caramel which was very good 
!

LOVE LOVE LOVE Smileys! Came here instead of waiting in the long lines at the food trucks during the Manayunk strEAT food festival. Got the beef platter and it comes with so much food for the price! It came with beef, rice, Greek salad, hummus and pita! I shared with my BF and it filled us up. I wanted to try their smoothies but didn't want to wait in line again. They have seating in the back which is comfy. Delicious and fresh! Will have to come back again when I'm in the area!

If you love to torture yourself with massive amounts of screaming children, and trashy girls looking for revealing costumes then come to masquerade!!!

I guess it's okay if you're into that pre-packaged Halloween thing, but that kind of makes my skin crawl. After going to the amazing Pierre's, I wandered into this place because I wanted a cheap tube of white greasepaint. That's it. To my amazement they carried ben nye makeup as well-- all marked up about 3 -5 dollars more than the place I was previously at. Super lame. However they do carry woochie prosthetics which is really cool.  

After I found the greasepaint, I went to go over to the line... which went from the registers wrapped around an aisle, and snaked to the back of the store. Ahhhhhhhhhhhh. Luckily, it only took me about 5 - 10 minutes to get to the front. I promptly checked out, and went outside only to notice there was now a line to get INTO the store. It went down the building towards the awesome bagel place.

All I know for sure is the day after halloween, they better discount the shit out of their inventory so I can go crazy with cheesy home decorations. Everyone needs a bleeding candle year round, don't they?

Situated over a natural spring and along the inner bay, this is a beautiful location to relax and get away. Spa services are excellent.  Staff is friendly and does a very good job of making you feel pampered. They use Aveda products (which I love!) I recommend looking through the many pkgs they offer for the resort. If you're a local, you may want to check out the mother &daughter day, week day, couples day, gentelmen's day, full day, or 1/2 day pkgs w/o accomodations.

Definitely a good new addition to our neck of the woods. I don't know why it took me so long to visit since this location opened a few months ago, but I'm glad we stopped in recently. The dining room was clean and well kept, and the staff was very friendly and accommodating. Our food was delivered promptly. The taco salads are insanely huge (gotta love the tortilla bowl too), and my husband was happy with his carnitas burrito. I'm sure we'll be back very soon!

I didn't even know what a praline was until I came here. WOW.  Melt in your mouth deliciousness. They are so indulgent and delicious!  You get to try samples of it first before you decide.  And there is someone there making them fresh as you walk around the store.

So many amazing choices.  I came here for the pralines and that's what I got. Loved the coconut one.  Also picked up some milk & dark chocolate peanut butter cups.  They had great looking king cakes, but that would've been a hassle for me to travel back with.

Just walking into the store, you can smell all the delectable sweet treats and I kinda feel like the aroma leaves with you a little.  Definitely make a stop here if you are visiting this city!

I was never really a believer of having a "stylist." I just wanted a decent cut at a low price, no matter where I was getting my hair cut or who was holding the scissors. Well, that's changed. 

I'd been going to a place for some time and getting my hair cut for $50 (plus tip), and I would walk out of the salon feeling .. not bad, but not great, about my hair. It was just, "meh, it's the same cut." 

So a friend of mine made an appointment for me with Amie, and I was nervous that I'd be paying for yet another cut I didn't love. I was wrong! Amie was talkative and very friendly, and very receptive of what I was looking for. I walked out with an amazing cut and a happy wallet - the shampoo, cut, and style was $25 (plus tip!) 

This was back in November, and I went this past week for another cut because my hair grew so quickly. I was a happy customer yet again. Now that I'm a repeat customer I had to write a review and recommend the shop to everyone!

My girlfriend and I just had a delightful lunch.

Lunch specials are $9.95, which includes an appetizer, an entrée and a beverage.

Our server was friendly and knowledgeable, and he gave us plenty of time to decide. There were many choices.

She got arancini, spinach ravioli and iced tea. And she ordered a dinner-sized portion of baked cannelloni to take home for dinner.

I got phyllo cigars, chicken madeira and Diet Coke.

Beverage refills were spot-on throughout our meal.

When the appetizers came out, they were fresh out of the fryer -- hot, but not killer hot. The arancini were sitting on a tomato-cheese sauce. The phyllo cigars were served with a tomato-based sauce.

We shared, so I got an arancini, and she got 1-1/2 phyllo cigars. They were both tremendously flavorful and full-bodied. The phyllo cigars were stuffed with dill feta. Besides risotto, the arancini were filled with gorgonzola and steak.

Our entrees were equally impressive, but less eaten. We were both kinda full -- not stuffed, but comfortable.

I took two bites of my tender chicken, which had a tomato and mushroom sauce, and two bites of zucchini (cut on the bias rather thickly to maintain its integrity) beautifully sautéed to the point of lovely browned crispness.

She took two bites of one ravioli, proclaimed it excellent, and we both took home a bunch o' food.

By the time we left, place was pretty filled up . . . just like we were.

I've had good service here. Quite helpful and friendly. They can get busy at times. But will take care of you when your time comes. 

Decent selection of phones. They stock the T-Mobile Tuesday freebies. Our dog loves her T-mobile bowtie and we have T-mobile umbrellas and super hero capes. They come in handy. 

Can you hear me now?

I have used this jewelry store since it opened.  Ya gotta love Sergio and now his son, friendly honest people.  I can't say I have bought a lot of jewelry here, but enough to take up some space. They used to do their own repairs, which I really appreciated, as I could often get my jewelry the same day or wait for a new clasp, or whatever I needed to fix the piece, sadly those days are gone. They send Rolex repairs out , but I will rival them against any other store on repairing and cleaning Rolex for a fair price.
All repairs are great, no complaints. The store has a large variety of jewelry pieces to offer and if you watch they often have some great sales. This is another Tampa independent family owned and operated, now into the next generation.
Once I dropped of a piece after the repair place had picked up orders and I really wanted to wear that piece in the near future, so they made an exception and dropped the piece off at the repair place, so I could receive it back in a timely manner.
Love local businesses and anyone that has read my posts knows this. Always happy when I can give them lots of stars and sad when I can't!
What's a girl to do? Always support your local business and shop there whenever possible.

This is where the cool kids hang and there's reasons for it. The beer and the food! Tons of vegetarian and even vegan options.
I'm not either but I do love that black bean burger and the salads are to die for.
The staff is great and always sweet and accommodating. 
The place is usually filled with great art and an eccentric lot of people. I gave this place five stars because I would be lying if I said I didn't love this place. It's my vibe.
It can be yours also.
Yup! Just referred to myself as a cool kid.:D

So I usually hate Yelp reviews that rant about the service. Because, I honestly think that if you're a true food lover, you wouldn't give a rats behind about service. Really good food speaks for itself. And it you wanted to be a big baby and spoon feed, you would have went to your mama's place. So with that aside, let's talk about Germantown Pub.

Food isn't good. Everything I've had here has been frozen and reheated/refried. From the fries to the catfish to the chicken tenders. Nothing here is made fresh in-house. So expect things to be overseasoned and oversalted to cover up for lack of freshness. And let's not forget how dry the food usually is. Like your great aunt's cooch, this food hasn't been moist in ages. 

The real insult to injury was the service our group received tonight. Our group of 12 came here for trivia which is actually really fun. And we're not the standard a-holes that move from our original seats, make tons of modifications to the menu and confuse our server. 

So, I was pretty freaking shocked when the server asked me what "number you were" like I was cattle or standing in line at the DMV when I tried to order another beer. When I asked her to clarify, she stated "I gave you a number when you sat down." Um no, you didn't because I would have actually asked you what you mean by number. I've worked in to service industry before so I understand large groups may be difficult but ultimately it's your JOB to remember who orders what. Blaming the customer for your lack of memorization makes the experience uncomfortable for everyone involved. She also claimed my friend's food would "be here in a moment" then 20 minutes later came back and accused him of never ordering it in the first place. Like seriously, we all heard him order it and then heard you confirm his order...twice. She also told me "don't get the Thai sauce on the chicken tenders...it's terrible." so I went with plain chicken tenders and just honey mustard on the side. But guess who ends up with the terrible Thai sauce on her chicken tenders, this girl. But I didn't even bother to send it back and ate my dry Thai sauced chicken tenders anyways because you can tell when things just weren't going ever be rectified. Also, not to the server's fault but due poor planning, ALL BUT ONE of the happy hour draft beers was available going into the 1st hour of trivia. Like, you guys didn't realize that as a bar on an event night you may want to have more beer available?

Short summary is, come here for the trivia and good company. Expect the happy hour beer to run out. Avoid the long red-headed server. And eat dinner elsewhere beforehand.

The only way I could afford this place on a semi-regular basis is during their happy hour, which features five different items for just $5 each from 5-7 pm. Two wines, two beers and a cheese plate. Lovely.

A friend and I shared a few things. A cheese plate, which was served with prosciutto, high quality olive oil and bread, followed by a small plate of figs and gorgonzola. The figs were smaller and tougher than I had hoped- they seemed previously dried, not fresh. An artichoke panino came next, which we subbed goat cheese for instead of feta- delicious. We wrapped up our meal with another sandwich- dessert, this time. I recommend the caramel, banana and marscapone cheese panino over anything else on the menu. Mmm...

I love Trader Joe's.  I've loved it in Chicago, I love it here. Love love love checking out dealson wine.   My only I only comnplaint (and why the negative one star) is that there is no Trader Joe's closer to downtown, and both of the local once are equally as inconvenient to get to.  I frequesntly buy cheese and wine here and their cocktail sauce is not bad! Not a fan of going on the weekends when it gets too crowded.

I don't really have great things to say about Ants Pants, but I also don't have many bad things to say either.  It's just...forgettable.  

First, it's cash only, as are most places in this area.  The wait for brunch on the weekends is insane and in my opinion, not worth it.  You can probably make many of their menu items at home, and save yourself some money too.

While the decor is cute and my mom loved the granola and yogurt (which is near $7...highway robbery!), I'd suggest walking down the street to Honey's or Resurrection.  You might have to wait a bit longer, but it will be worth it.

Midtown is the nicest liquor store in the area, in my opinion. When you walk in, classical music is playing and they just have that high end feel while browsing. They also know what the hell they are talking about people!

They have a fabulous liquor and wine selection, and are eager to offer a suggestion or opinion on what they carry. Complaints... they aren't the most cost efficient place in town (though not crazily so, just noticeable) and since times have been a bit tighter financially for me lately, I feel like a bit of a bum shopping here for my box o' wine or cheap selections. 

You know what I mean. I actually wanted a boxed wine recommendation (I prefer bottles but you've gotta do what you gotta do) but I noticed I wasn't approached once when I was in that area, whereas other sections will get you some customer service. Oh well, I guess it was less embarrassing to just grab my box and get the heck out of there before I was judged too harshly. 

But I do love shopping here, especially if I can afford something of the nicer variety!

My boyfriend and I stopped in because we realized we had a coupon from our Indianapolis Entertainment book.

The woman behind the counter who explained that the offerings at the subway-style set up change every week, and the menu was their catering menu. 
She served us and was very very friendly, and it was enjoyable being served by her. It seems like most of the staff are very friendly and knowledgeable.
She let us try one bite of everything they had to offer in little sample cups. There is a wide variety of flavours, very spicy to very mild. 

The chutneys are something you should avoid if you do not like spicy food. They will also offer you some yogurt-sour cream sauce stuff if you are a big wimp, or accidentally put chutney in your mouth and it is now burning and numb at the same time and you are desperate for relief.

I really liked the butter chicken, and opted to order that. My boyfriend ordered the chicken curry but I forget what it was called. Both tasted great and were very filling, I even had enough leftovers for lunch the next day. He horked it down to fast for leftovers. We also bought a lemony dessert ball thing. It was yummy, if you see a lemony dessert ball thing being offered by the register you should try it. 
We also bought naan. We did not like the naan and threw it away, it was tough and sort of chewy and singed. We did come right before close though, so this could simply be because it wasnt fresh naan? My other thought is that I would love if I could add some mixed vegetables or something to the curry, because it is sauce and meat only. I know that is not exactly traditional, but it would be nice to have the option IMO

The chicken here is amazing!  The last time I ad authentic Peruvian rotisserie chicken was at malecon in NY. The skin is crispy and flavorful and the meat juicy. I ordered a whole chicken meaning to save half but...  Oh well, it'll be time to hit the gym. After my sat gorge fest at a NY style deli of course but I digress. Anyhow great food and friendly people. I'll definitely be back because I love my meat.

I am not known for my meat-eating abilities. Pampa nearly killed me. I don't like bacon (seriously, I know - please keep reading, I promise I will redeem myself one day). I am more of a starchy, carby kind of person. When it comes to most meats, I'm sort of... .indifferent. Sometimes I even willingly choose to eat tofu. But whenever someone suggests to go eat at Sloppy Hoggs, I'm all for it. In fact, I'm the one driving. And cheering as I drive.

I was initially very wary of going for BBQ due to all of the above. But going into Sloppy Hoggs, I got a great first impression. The restaurant is clean, very minimal and laid out nicely. It is a rather small space (and at times it can be near impossible to get a table) but the smell of meat emanating through the restaurant is amazing (AND doesn't cloak you in meat cologne stench).

My significant other is the polar opposite of me - huge meat eater, lover of bacon, barbequed anything, red meat monster. I went because of him and watched him consume a huge platter of pulled pork. I was a little daunted but I ordered The Cure, which I had to admit I thoroughly enjoyed. Fried egg, amazing waffles, pulled pork, bacon (which I even ate!), some sort of sweet sauce, flavor, flavor, more flavor and sweet potato fries. So good.

So we went again. And then I tried the pulled pork. Then we went again and I had the chicken. And the cornbread. And honestly, it has never disappointed me, other than the days when they literally couldn't give us a table due to multiple reservations and lack of seating (and this has happened several times). But that blip aside, we keep coming back. It's just that good. For a bacon-fanatic, meat lovin place, I, the meat-indifferent, love it all the same. Bravo, Sloppy Hoggs, bravo.

Great atmosphere and love the decor. Stopped in with friends for a quick drink early evening. Not expecting $13 for a drink. With tax and tip, $20 is hefty drink pricing.  A bit over the top in my opinion. The waiter was rather snooty which made me chuckle. It's in a sketchy area that thinks very highly of its self. Hipster food choices. Not the run of the mill bar food. I highly doubt I would go out of my way to go back

I am really glad that we have this type of ice cream shop in the Tampa area. What I love most about rolled ice cream shops like this is watching them make your ice cream! I got a cookies and cream ice cream with mochi, whipped cream, and chocolate pocky sticks. It was so good! The serving was pretty big for me, so I would definitely share it with someone next time. The cashier was really friendly. It took about 10 minutes to get the ice cream. The atmosphere is super casual. The only downside that I found was that there weren't enough seats/tables to accommodate all the customers. I think I went at a pretty good time on a Saturday afternoon because I was able to beat the long line of customers that came in after me. I would definitely come back again to try their other flavors!

An indoor bounce house. My 1.5 yr old loved it! She was a bit frightened at first bit warmed up in 10 minutes. She jumped and slid to her hearts content! Plus her age was FREE! Great times for toddlers !

I really love that they brought more acai bowls to Valrico...that's one thing we're lacking over here. In my opinion, it could of used more acai at the bottom. They don't blend it with almond milk like everyone else, so instead of a fluffy smoothie texture, its small and icy. The toppings were great and the granola (that they make in house) was tasty. Worth a try!

Do you like bagels dripping with organic crunchy peanut butter and ooey gooey jam? WHAT AM I SAYING OF COURSE YOU DO. Get thee to La Va.

Seriously good stuff. I'm not much of a coffee drinker, so sorry to be unhelpful that department. What I can tell you is that Brian (hi Brian!) makes a mean PB&J bagel and pours a thirst-quenching OJ faster than you can say LAVA! (I pronounce it LA-va rather than la-VA, which is just more fun that way).

Loved this neighborhood, and this cafe in particular. Tell Brian I said hi.

I had a really nice lunch at Kawa with my husband and one of my daughters last week. The parking lot is a bit tight but we were able to get a spot - it was the holiday season though, and I think it probably gets a little more hectic during a usual work week.  Something to keep in mind.

Our waitress was so sweet and helpful.  The food was great and presented beautifully - the dishes they used were all so cool that I wanted to take them home (I think the waitress was laughing at me a little as I oohed and ahhed over everything).  Loved the décor as well, from the tables to the seat cushions to the artwork on the walls. It's not a large space, but it's not too small either.  Overall, there's a really cool vibe in the place.

The food was really good - we tried a bunch of stuff.  We started with the fried vegetable spring rolls (two per order - we should have gotten two orders, or maybe they should add one more?  it wasn't enough of an appetizer for three people). My daughter enjoyed her sushi platter (it came with a nice little salad) and my husband liked his ramen soup.  I had a steak teriyaki platter which came with some really good rice and sautéed veggies (I actually ate my meal with chopsticks - first time ever!  So what if I had to stab the steak pieces!?!).  My meal also came with a cup of miso soup - it was good but I just don't see what's so special about miso soup.

We ended the meal with the green tea snow ice which was tasty - the interesting part was the sweet beans that are served along with it.  Yes, actual beans - sort of like baked beans with the sugar but not the BBQ flavor.  It was served on a bed of mangos or peaches - we couldn't figure out which.

We really enjoyed our experience at Kawa. You should definitely check it out sometime...  I think it will be around for a long time.

tomato basil soup, omg delicious.

bbq chicken flatbread is good when I'm eating it but then I feel sick afterwards.

My bf loves the curry chicken but I'm not a big fan of any of Cosi's sandwiches.

I can definitely see why people love to stop in here to grab a coffee or a quick bite, but it was honestly a bit of a brunch letdown after reading all the good reviews. I came here with a group of friends this weekend (6 of us total) because I didn't want to try getting in at one of the usual brunch spots and having to wait for hours. Seating was easy, and we pushed together a few tables to accommodate everyone.

However, the food choices are a little strange and not extremely descriptive. I split the jalepeno cornbread and the mushroom frittata with my boyfriend. Both main items were extremely small (like 5 bites) and came with a small arugula side salad. All the flavors were just okay. For $9 each, I felt like the price point wasn't quite right, especially for this neighborhood. One friend ordered a green tea cupcake that came out very hard and dry, like it had been made days ago. The best-looking dish by far was a vegan sandwich off the lunch menu. 

I was happy with my latte and happy with the ambiance, but this place isn't in my 'hood and I honestly probably won't be back. Oh well.

I love Pf Changs. they deliver a quality product every time. I've never had a bad experience. My husband and I went there after a disaster of a night at another local restaurant. We arrived around 915p on a Friday night. we were sat and greeted immediately. I ordered the agave margarita. if you haven't tried it, please do. it's easily one of my top 5 favorite margaritas. for dinner I ordered the lettuce wraps. I wasn't starving. and they are a great go to app. my husband ordered hunan-style hot fish. loved it. was spicy and perfectly cooked. this meal really helped us bounce back from a rocky night. prices are great and service is always good. people might not think so highly of chain restaurants, but Pf Changs delivers a consistent high quality product.

Love this store although it's only been there a couple of years. With the hot sauce shop gone in Peddlers village this is a nice addition. A small shop with plenty to take in. As soon as you walk in the aromas of the spices hit you like a wall.  Although pleasing to me and many others it might not be your cup of tea. A definite gourmet of spices and great cooking ideas. I could not just choose one. They even have genuine extracts. Not just vanilla, but butterscotch, espresso and rum. The blend of spices and seasonings which many have testers. You can sniff and taste before you buy which is right up my alley. They have a decent selection of pepper spices, chilli powders from all over and even some gourmet curries. Pink salt if that's your thing to dried hot peppers to cinnamon. Their grilling rubs sound delicious. They are moderately to run of the mill price some are expensive depending on what you pick. But a grocery store can sell you a watered down version of curry powder for 5 bucks and less than 3 oz. Why not pay a little extra and get a damn amazing curry powder that has flavor. Definitely worth a stop in you never know what flavors await..

I'm not a vegetarian, but I do love eating here!  The prices can be a bit steep for fast casual food, but the flavors make it worth it. The chickn burger is huge and very tasty. My fiancé usually ends up getting this sandwich and I get the Philly steak (clearly a play on a cheesesteak). The food is always hot which makes me happy that it's not sitting under a heat lamp. 

The sides are a bit pricey as the meals don't come with a side, but know that the sides are large proportions. You could make a meal out of a side alone.  Always always always go with the sweet potato fries and sriracha aioli.

Mommy wow. I'm a big kid now... is exactly how I felt coming to the Children's Museum with my little lady! We absolutely love this museum and we have annual passes, so we go about twice a month :) 

We in particularly loved going two days after Thanksgiving for the Jolly days!  We went down the great big snow slide which was a blast for me and my little one! The winter wonderland was so perfect! It really was a wonderful and fit all ages. 

Lastly, our favorite part of the museum is the toddlers playscape. My little one LOVES this exhibit. It's safe and she can run all over the place and be independent. From blocks, to the music room, to the jungle gym, to playing with sand - it's the perfect storm of activity to tire my baby out right in time for nap time. 

The most awesome thing about the playscape space are the nursing mothers rooms with comfy chairs, toys and TVs for mommy to be entertained while feeding!!! So awesome and thoughtful ;)

Positively gorgeous and worth a walk-through.

My friends and I hopped over after touring the Grand Ole Opry. We *almost* skipped the Gaylord Opryland due to the parking situation. The only lot we could find was $18, which was ridiculous considering we only wanted to walk around for an hour or so. We ended up parking across the street at Cracker Barrel and walking over. It's not a long haul, but it's not short either. (We might have been better off staying where we'd parked for the Opry, not sure.)

Once we got into the Gaylord Opryland, though, we were SO glad we came. We started in the main lobby with the waterfalls, then went through to the next section with the gazebo and gardens, then continued past the pool to the Delta atrium, with its river, restaurants, and dancing fountain. Each section was absolutely lovely, like a small (climate-controlled) paradise. Between our two cameras, we must have taken a few hundred photos.

After walking around for over an hour, we decided to sit and relax at a bar/cafe in the first section (just off the main lobby). Though we didn't try anything off the menu (because we had reservations at the Bluebird Cafe) it did look very tasty and reasonably priced.

We all agreed we would love to come back someday, possibly to stay in the hotel, possibly just to walk around at night or at the holidays when things were lit up.

I love this grocery store.  The only reason I am not giving it 5 stars is because I cannot leave with everything I need on my shopping list.  

I first came about the Turnip Truck when I moved to the gultch.   I would go when I randomly forgot something at the store.  However, now I go at least twice a week for all of my meat purchases. 

I am my mothers daughter and very picky about the meat I buy.  I love when I buy the meat at TT it is packaged that day.  How much fresher can you get?!?

I'm in Indianapolis almost every other month because my lovely sister just had a baby girl. Normally, we just stay in and I cook. But I was absolutely craving some Chinese food this week. I googled some places and Dragon House Chinese Eatery had decent reviews and was a short drive away.

We ordered the Family Dinner for 4 Special which came with spring rolls or soup, fried rice, lo mein, and 2 meat entrees for $23.99 -- great deal there, you can't go wrong! We ordered the spring rolls, veggie fried rice, veggie lo mein, chinese vegetables and sesame chicken. Additionally, we got crab rangoon and singapore noodles. Overall, the food was okay but for our group tasted underseasoned. The singapore noodles were very delicious and had a great curry flavor though. The sesame chicken also had a great flavor. But the rest, eh. Not my favorite. But hit the spot for a quick Chinese food take out craving.

Customer service was fantastic. I was able to call and place my order with ease and my food was ready in 15 minutes. Inside, the restaurant is clean and nicely decorated. Other reviews said the buffet is great so maybe eat in.

I loved everything I had heard about H & W before visiting this location - lower prices, fresh produce, and a local business.  Unfortunately I was unimpressed and disappointed with my visit.  The store was small, and felt run down and dirty.  There were pieces of squished fruits and vegetables all over the floor, and herds of kids and adults bumping into me and my cart as I tried to shop.  

The prices are somewhat lower than a normal grocery store, but I found nothing exceptional in terms of freshness.  The avocados and tomatoes were so under-ripe I had to go to Safeway after to finish my shopping, and items that I had been hoping would be of better quality/freshness than a grocery store (i.e. green beans, red peppers) were just as sad and uninspiring as anything at Sobey's or Safeway.  

When ringing up my purchases, the cashier keyed in at least three of my items incorrectly, perhaps more while I was getting my wallet and bags out.  Given that H & W is an extra 10 minute drive from home, the produce wasn't anything special and that I couldn't wait to escape the crowded cramped aisles, I won't be back - the experience wasn't worth the few dollars savings.

**** 3 1/2 Stars****

We came to. Effoc's for brunch on our last day in Delaware. It's a small cafe in Wilmington. My friend described it perfectly: good food, good prices, but the place smells of their cooking so be prepared to smell like brunch. Heeding her warning, we opted to sit outside. Luckily it was a nice day. 

We looked over the menu and then placed our orders inside. I opted for the vegetarian egg white omelette with lots of vegetables! Loved the spinach and avocado! They also have several beverage options. I chose coffee and the peach mango smoothie. Cool and refreshing. 

The prices are good and staff is friendly. Effoc's does smell like their food on the inside though. Not a negative, just a comment.

I don't really understand the fascination with Han Dynasty. My friend and I came for dinner and neither of us were impressed. 

The spice/heat rating attached to the foods is ridiculous. Really, a scale of 1 to 10? Anything above 5 is hot enough to make you not able to taste any of your food, so what's the point?

The steamed dumplings had hardly any meat in them at all. Literally it was like the size of a nickel, and they were covered in chili oil. Actually, that's really my main complaint with all of the food, it's just covered in chili oil. I love chili oil and cook with it all the time, but just dousing food in it really isn't good cooking. 

My meal and my friend's meal were both just OK. She got the garlic sauce style and I got the double cooked style. Again, both were floating in chili oil.

The only real reason this place stuck out above the rest was with it's staff - they were very friendly, if not borderline overbearing.

I'm giving 3 stars because nothing was "bad," but I'd never go here again when there are so many other places I have yet to try.

I lived in Atlanta for 16 years and I have been to Zaxby's several times. My friends that went to UGA in Athens, GA love this place. I think they have a good quality product, and generally speaking a clean environment.  I tried the location on Waters and Dale Mabry and the product is consistent.

They have a plate called Wings and Things. I supersized it and had a bunch of wings, chicken tenders, French fries, celery and Texas toast. I paid around $10 and it was definitely a lot of food. The chicken tenders were excellent!!! great flavor, moist and...well, tender. The chicken wings were really good, they have 9 different flavors and I went with the Tongue torch, equivalent to a Buffalo sauce. I'd have them again.
French fries....good, toast... good.

In an objective review I would give them 4 stars. I believe the price for the wings is more consistent with that of a larger restaurant where you get full service; although they make an effort to have a nice décor inside, it's really a fast food restaurant.

Now...what's up with that poster at the entrance of the Serengeti in Africa and a feline violently biting into a Zebra? I thought that was a little disturbing. My ex is vegetarian and I used to go with her to Zaxby's and she would have a grilled cheese. If she would have gotten to this store we would have had to turn around and look for some other place. This is an opinion and a very personal judgment that might not affect other customers. 

I would recommend their chicken tenders and their wings, and I can see myself at the Drive Thru picking some up again.

My favorite ice cream stop!!! So yummy. These are all homemade! They constantly have great flavors, which makes  it so hard to pick just one. That is why I always have two different flavors. My favorites are the green tea and cotton candy! Lately Iv been getting the peanut butter one too! Live music sucks but I love the atmosphere

Now, I'm not some hillbilly that reviews gas stations. I live in the city, for chrissakes! But, because I live in the city, I'm unaccustomed to gas stations the size of airports. Well, we just got our first in that category and I'm impressed. 

I love that it's large enough that you don't have to wait to get gas because all the pumps are full. More importantly, I'm embarrassed to say, the convenient mart is a pretty fun shopping experience.

They have it all - a big selection of booze with an entire walk-in beer case. They have pre-made sandwiches/salads/wraps that look every bit as good as something you'd get at the Schnucks or Dierbergs deli. For breakfast, you can get fresh donuts, sourdough breakfast sandwiches, etc. They have every darn kind of fountain drink that you could possibly want - including an Icee machine that you can fill with your own flavor choice (!) and some kind of ice cream shake machine. Unbelievably, they have some staples like a small selection of produce and an impressive selection of breads. They also have healthy car treats, packed in containers that fit into your cup holder. What haven't they thought of?

The customer service is ridiculous too. You are always greeted by someone when you walk in. Do these people know that they work in a gas station? Every last one of them has been pleasant on every stop.

So, here...I've gone and reviewed a gas station and gave it 5 stars. And I don't care because it's pretty freaking cool, as far as gas stations go. Welcome to South City!

Great large menu with lots of choices. Fun bubble tea flavors! I loved the crab and chicken rolls appetizer as well as the lemongrass beef. Both were very tasty. The noodle bowl I got was okay. I'll order a different main dish next time.

Love the concept of this restaurant but execution is inconsistent. Every time I've eaten here there has been something cooked incorrectly with at least one person's meal. In addition the food is kind of lack luster. I can recreate all of these dishes at home to meet the dietary guidelines and still provide high quality product with great flavor composition. However, when you're in a pinch and need a quick lunch it's nice to have somewhere that you don't have to guess on the ingredients. Also love the olive oil shots!

I come here often to watch soccer games with my boyfriend. The food is good, we really enjoyed he portobello fries and they have amazing wings! If the service is something that defines your dining experience, this is NOT the place for you. The service is poor to say the least. All of my dining experiences here I have felt like I was imposing on our server and they were not busy in the slightest. I am a server as well, and you have GOT to be polite to customers, for the love of God. If you like to grab a beer and sit at the bar, this is a good place for you.

I just got an email from the vendor:  their next annual conference is in New Orleans.  What's more, it's in the French Quarter!  Cool, gotta go back to Preservation Hall . . .

Preservation Hall is probably unlike any other place in the world.  N'Awlyns is acknowledged as the birthplace of Jazz, and The Hall is a living musical history of that era.  All the way down to the building, a dirty-looking hole-in-the-wall that you'd want to pass by if you didn't know what is in there.  Pay your admission, crowd your way in, and listen to the musicians blow.

I was in town for Jazz Fest, so I felt like I had to go here, otherwise I'm missing something.  The set was only three songs long, and I knew only "Back Home Again In Indiana", but it was still a top experience.  The music was very good, and you could tell that the musicians loved what they were doing.  It felt like I was back at the turn of the *last* century.

I'd want my daughter to hear this in person, but I clicked NOT good for kids.  Waiting in line in humid Crescent City, then standing the whole time in a stuffy room, makes for cranky kids.  Bad for them, bad for the parents, bad for the audience.  I'm sure there's a similar place like this in this city that's more suitable for them with all that jazz.

You can get recordings of the same music and same personnel, but it's not like seeing them in person at Preservation Hall.  Actually, Café du Monde is also a must-do, but if you can do only one of those, I'd say to choose Preservation Hall.

Big laugh:  When I went, there was a small sign up:
REQUESTS: $1
POPULAR SONGS:  $2
SAINTS:  $5
In other words, if you insist on them playing "When The Saints Go Marching In" yet again, it's gonna cost ya!

ECSTATIC to have Ragin' Daisy back in my life for all things girly. I used to frequent the shop when it was Uptown, now it is right around the corner from my work in the Quarter. 
From Tutus to barrettes, vintage dresses to make-up, this is your place. I even found a watering can that I must go back and get pronto because it is too embarassing to water your plants out of an old milk jug. Especially when you can have one shaped like a Lucky Cat or a frog!  Another bonus, the women who work here are so friendly ( a rarity in the retail underworld) and remembered my face from YEARS ago. Wow. 
Need a costume, or maybe gift for a lady in your life? She'll love you if you come on down to Ragin' Daisy.

I frequently visit the Tria on 18th St and love it but I was looking to try one of their other locations. I'm a big fan of their Claudio Panini but this time I ordered their Prosciutto Cotto Panini and it was just okay. It was a little bit spicy and I definitely felt like I was missing out on something. Other than that the atmosphere at Tria is wonderful and I will always go back!

Delivery! The food has always arrived hot and as ordered. The portions are large and we can feed four with two entrees, rice, and crab puffs. The flavors were good without being overly sweet or salty. We love the Moo Shu (chicken or pork), cashew chicken, fried rice, pork egg rolls, and crab puffs.
We have only just found this place but I'm sure everything is delicious.

I have been here twice and were quite disappointed by the inconsistency in quality. The first time everything was great. We ordered grilled chicken, lamb, and shrimp. The last one is exceptionally well done so I ordered it the second time I was there. But it turned out to be burnt and a little too salty for my taste. 

Besides this, I love the atmosphere and the price is very reasonable. Will give it another try.

the lunch buffet here is very solid. i was pleasantly surprised by the amount of vegetarian options! usually i find buffets are half meat half veg, but this was like 75% veg. i don't know if i just caught them on a veg heavy day, but i loved that. there was so much to try! all the food was super tasty. i'll definitely be back.

Awesome food truck! I've had them a couple of times at different events in the Tampa Bay area. Service was friendly both times. Lines can get pretty long as this is a popular truck. Food truck stands out and love the name!

I've only had the chicken and waffles so far. Chicken is fried perfectly- not greasy and is seasoned well. Waffle is crispy on the outside and fluffy on the inside. They serve it up w/ syrup and honey mustard. It's a full size portion so prices are on point for what you get. I will need to order a dessert waffle next time!

Lit-erally one of the cutest wine bars in the city and a perfect 104th Street hot spot. This Italian style wine bar is always packed and buzzing. Although, it is hard not to be busy in a place that is so, in a word, Lit-tle. With seating for around 30, not the most comfortable in the world, mind you, it does well to have a reservation if you are going to be a guest.  The Italian menu reads like Lit-erature (I know, I couldn't help it!), sparkling with Italian classics such as antipastos, olives, flat breads and pastas.  The wine list is excellent as well, as one would expect from a venue de vino. The deconstructed environment is sparsely decorated with a few paintings and Lit-hographs (I swear, that is the last one) by local artists.

So go fall in love with Lit. What can I say... sometimes, it's all in the name!

I've been eating here for 10 years or something like that and I've had various luck.  I've always enjoyed coming here and I have to insist that the original menu and it's variations for the first few years were much better than it is now.  They're going through some changes and it's painful.  

I had come here in December and had a terrible meal and the GM invited us back to try them again.  I was kinda thinking that before he wrote me that it had been my last visit.  We ate here last night and had a very good experience.  Of course, we received some special attention (the service last time wasn't good) last night was terrific.  We liked everything but the duck dish.  Even the oysters, still not nearly the best in NOLA, were decent.  

I liked the burrata salad a lot, it's really well balanced and was perfectly dressed.  Miriam's Luke salad similarly so but over salted.  Still edible but over salted.  

I liked her shrimp and grits a lot.  Too shrimpy for me, not my thing, but I appreciated it anyway.  She loved it.  I liked the grits and sausage.  The duck dish is too much.  Too sweet, too rich, too much rice, too salty.  It's cloying in the end.  The duck was prepared perfectly and it was delicious.  I loved the texture and preparation of the rice too.  I doubt anyone finishes this dish.  1/3rd of the rice, a little more confit and maybe a small pile of those great Brussels sprouts on the side would be perfect.  

We love their French press so we finished with some coffee and some of the best creme brûlée in NOLA.  The biscotti is a complete miss.  Heavy and made by someone who doesn't have a clue.  These are easy to make, by the way.  

Here's a big problem though.  It's a corporate restaurant.  Upper management here is ruining this place.  They're still serving the worst bread in NOLA, they know it, and are still serving it.  When you have people making decisions for your restaurant who don't work there and don't know anything about food you're in trouble.  It's just about the money.  It makes it impossible to create and execute a clear vision about the food your serving and why you're serving it.  How can you serve a product you know is bad and do it anyway?  Can't be 4 stars until they decide that their staff can make decisions about the food and they focus their vision about what the heck this place is supposed to be about.  Says a lot about the Besh group.... sadly.

My husband and are so excited that we found this place! While living in Arlington, VA we tried Ethiopian for the first time and fell in love with it. We had a favorite restaurant we would go to often so when we moved here earlier this year we wanted to find a new favorite. We tried St Yared and that experience left us disappointed. Our experience here was a complete 180!

Service 3/5
Service was as expected. Our waitress was friendly and got our order right. The restaurant wasn't super busy but I had to flag her down a couple times because she just didn't check on us very often, not a huge deal though. Our food didn't take too long and it was hot when we go it.

Atmosphere/Ambiance 3/5
The restaurant feels very dated and not very warm. But it was clean and the seats were comfortable enough. They also have a bottle of hand sanitizer at each table which is nice. This is probably a strange thing to mention but they had an electronic sign at the back of the restaurant that blinked between the word "coffee" and the picture of a coffee mug in neon colors and that was fairly distracting actually. Next time I'll try to remember to sit on the opposite side of the table, my husband isn't bothered by things like that as much as I am!

Food 5/5
Let's be honest, we didn't come here for the service or the atmosphere, we came here for the food and the food was most definitely the star of the show! We got our usual entrees...my husband got the Kitfo and I got the beef Awaze Tibs (mild) and both were absolutely delicious! They tasted exactly the same as what we got at our favorite restaurant in Arlington. We are beyond excited and will absolutely be back!

Delicious!!!!!!!!!!!!!! My bf and I just returned from brunch at Centennial, and we are both fully satisified with our meals!

First off, let me say... we were on our way to the White Dog Cafe. On a whim, my bf suggested we try the Centennial.  Recalling that a co-worker of mine ALWAYS brought tasty-looking danishes and muffins to work from Centennial, I wholeheartedly agreed to give it a try.

I ordered the shrimp and grits. I loved it! It was served PIPING HOT with mushrooms, onions, tomatos, and cheese and of course, grits. it reminded me of a cajun dish like shrimp creole or jambalaya.  I wish they served something else with it though, because after a while, you do need something else to break up that taste.   My bf shared his french toast with me, which solved that problem.

He ordered french toast, eggs, turkey sausage links, and potatos w/ onions and peppers. To drink, he had a hazelnut steamer and I had my usual cup of darjeeling with cream and sugar.

The only complaint I have with this place is that they are slightly overpriced.  My breakfast was 12.95, and his was $12.95. Our grand total was $33.oo, which I think is a lot for breakfast.

Overall, I'd highly recommend this place and will be returning.

What a hidden gem!!! Giving them four stars BC of the limited seatings but I loved this place, cool vibe, great music and awesome drinks!! Saturday nite it was busy BC its not a very big space. Seating was limited its a first come first serve seating. It took awhile to order our drinks but once we put in the order it came super quick. I would definitely be back. Very cool little spot near plenty of restaurant and shopping as well.

If you could go to one tasting place in Santa Barbara, I'd recommend this one!  Although I love Kalyra wines, I think this place is fun because they have so much of a variety, with wine and beer flights.  They have a traditional beer tastings, as well as fruit beers.  You can apply the flight price to your wine/beer purchase, which is always a plus.  

The flights are pretty affordable (normal for the area), with a range of options for different prices (i.e., chardonnay/white tastings are cheaper than some cab/red tastings).  

This is the best place to take a group, even if they are newbies to the wine/beer tasting world.  The location is great - take a walk along the coast after you taste!

The only reason I give this place four stars instead of five, is because the staff weren't the friendliest.  Not rude, but not nice and welcoming either.  But I've only been here once, so maybe next time my experience with the staff would be different.

Fantastic location if you want to be close to Broadway & the downtown sights. The staff were all so friendly & accommodating & went the extra mile by providing area suggestions & assisting us in renting & parking our car (special shout-out to Andrea for her helpfulness (I hope I remembered her name correctly!)). Our room was on the 13th floor (I thought all hotels skipped the 13th floor?) & had recently been remodeled. I loved, LOVED the fact they used faux wooden flooring instead of the typical carpet (I hate carpet, it's so dirty & grosses me out!) & they did a great job on the bathroom, particularly the beautiful shower & the makeup light around the mirror. The hotel provides ample complimentary Aveda toiletries (shampoo/conditioner, body lotion, mouthwash, etc) as well as a sewing kit, cotton balls & swabs, & makeup remover wipes- all very impressive in my opinion, as I've never seen so many complimentary items in one hotel room before. There is a nice bar area downstairs & although they do not have a separate restaurant, they do have a pretty decent menu to order from & you can enjoy your meal at the bar or in the ample seating/lounge area. They also keep a constant rotation of complimentary pastries & cookies in the front desk area so that was another nice touch offered by Hotel Indigo. I like how they've kept some of the original features of the building in their design, such as the big windows & the mail shoot found across from the elevators on each floor. I highly recommend Hotel Indigo Nashville if you're going to be visiting the area.

Tutti Toscani has been a south jersey favorite of mine for a long, long time... Even predating my yelp reviewing days (feeling nostalgic!). I've hosted a baby shower here and was so incredibly impressed with how accommodating the staff was and how incredible our service was.

I was here last night with my family and was not disappointed one but. We started with the family style appetizer, with fried calamari, fried zucchini and mussels in red. All were Perfectly prepared and the portions were appropriate for sharing.

For my main course I had the fettuccine bolognese, which had generous helpings of ground meat. My mom had the eggplant rollatini served with spinach ravioli.  Both were delicious, and I was impressed with the spinach ravioli- you could really taste the spinach!! My dad had the mussels as clams and considering he left nothing but a bunch of empty shells in his bowl, I'm guessing he was satisfied.

I didn't get to try my brother (penne al vodka) or sister in law (rigatoni with chicken, sausage and broccoli rabe)'s dishes but looked and smelled delicious and I saw some happy-food-dances going on, mid-consumption.

Oh! I forgot out the bread! How can I forget the heaping basket of fresh rolls and tomato pie that we were greeted with!? Nothing but love for that basket. 

This is a Byob in the heart of South Jersey that you won't want to miss out on.

Wonderful little neighborhood coffee shop.  I have yet to try the food, but I would love to if it worked out.  The coffee / espresso is delicious and not overpriced.  

I do have to recommend the Vanilla Chai though- it's spectacular.  

They have plenty of space inside and out to sit and study or just relax.  I was using LaVa as a study break from my house for a little while and always felt very comfortable.  They have a water cooler which is nice too.  Baristas are very sweet.

A little note that made me like this place even more is that although they have a $10 minimum for payments made by CC- they suggested I get a $10 gift card and use it so I'll have a "free" coffee next time I come in.  I'm not sure why other places with minimums don't suggest this as well!  It worked for me :)

I've been wanting to try this place for quite some time given the stellar yelp reviews. After finally squeaking through the door last night just before 8 pm, I can now say I agree with its good reputation! It is truly a gem in the neighborhood. I love that it is BYOB. At ~6.50 a plate, Sky Cafe boasts street food prices, but the dining area is nicer than I expected given the cheap prices: it's clean, comfortable, and well-decorated. Although my friend had to take my order over the phone at 7:45 as I rushed there before closing, the waiter was patient and excellent at recommending a vegetarian dish I would enjoy. He was very helpful and polite and he never made us feel rushed.

Now, on to the food. Everything was fresh and arrived speedily to the table. My friends both got the Mie Kepiting (homemade egg noodles with crab meat). The noodles were phenomenal; a delightful and unique combination of texture and flavor. The noodles and crab meat are in one bowl, and the broth is served on the side, so you can pour it in to suit your ideal ratio of noodles: broth. I got the Nasi Urap with what were described to me as "stinky beans" (I did not find them very stinky at all, which is a good thing). The beans came in a rich, spicy, coconutty sauce that I absolutely adored. The plate came with a nest of assorted crispy fried vegetables, which complimented the texture of the beans and rice perfectly. I was a little disappointed there were not more vegetarian items on the menu, considering the many vegan options available at other Indonesian restaurants in the area, but apparently they can make several dishes to order, so I would love to come back and try a vegetarian version of the noodles if they have it.

I'm so glad I finally tried this place! I'll be back for sure.

I've been a fan of Nino's for a very long time. I don't make it there very often since I moved away from p-town.

Story time:
Back in the day when they first opened  ('96-ish) my high school friends and I would go here. Often we didn't have the cash so we'd split plates. Nino (the owner) would see us doing this and would give us extra food because "growing kids have got to eat!".  

During this time my mom had cancer so when she'd actually feel like eating I'd call in a pickup order for her. He'd tell me to stay home and take care of my mom and he'd have his kitchen help run down the street to my house to hand deliver it. "Fresh food help you feel better fast 'eh?"

Several years later when one of the high school gang died suddenly my hubs and I stopped by Nino's after the funeral. After he heard what happened he refused to let us pay for lunch and then poured us two very large glasses of red wine. 
"Some times wine and a full stomach makes bad things a bit easier" 
Yes Nino, yes it does.
 
I love Nino... he's a character and a very very nice guy.

The restaurant used to be a toddle house when I moved to the 'hood. Nino redid it into a cafeteria style Italian restaurant. It's smallish with 4 or 5 tables on the inside and 4 tables on the outside. Daily he picks 2-3 dishes and makes them from scratch. Everything is very very fresh.  Watching him make the bread and dough is pretty awesome.
